titleStmt.title: A Lexicon of the Homeric Dialect
titleStmt.author: Richard John Cunliffe

monogr.author: Richard John Cunliffe
monogr.title: A Lexicon of the Homeric Dialect.

div.p: Γ?̔θοοί, μεγάθυμοι, μένεα πνείοντες, ὄπιθεν κομόωντες).
The men of Euboea Il. 2.536, 541, 542, Il. 4.464.
Mother by Boucolion of Aesepus-2 and Pedasus-3 (twins) Il. 7.22.
With his brother Polyidus-1 killed by Diomedes Il. 5.148.
An unknown race so described Il. 13.6.
A city on the s.e. of the Hellespont, a little below Sestus on the other side Il. 2.836.
A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.249.
Adj. fr. Ἀγαμέμνων Il. 10.326, Il. 23.295, 525: Od. 3.264.
(ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν, βασιλεύς, δὶος, εὐρὺ κρείων, κλυτός, κοσμήτωρ λαῶν, κρείων, κύδιστος, πελώριος, ποιμὴν λαῶν).
King of Mycenae and great suzerain of the Greeks.
Son of Atreus, brother of Menelaus, husband of Clytemnestra, and father by her of Orestes-3, Chrysothemis, Laodice-2 and Iphianassa.

in the assembly summoned by Achilles abuses Calchas Il. 1.106, addresses A. and proposes to send back Chryseis 131, addresses him again and threatens to take Briseis from him 173, addresses Nestor 286;

has a ship prepared to carry back Chryseis Il. 1.308, bids the people cleanse themselves 313, sends his heralds to bring away Briseis 320; Zeus sends Oneirus to beguile him Il. 2.8, he summons the council of chiefs and relates his dream 53, the sceptre bequeathed to him by Thyestes 107, addresses the assembly and counsels a return home 110, assents to the opposite counsel of Nestor 370, summons the host to the fight 441;
described on the walls by Helen to Priam Il. 3.172;
prays to Zeus and performs the oath-sacrifice Il. 3.276;
sends for Machaon to see the wounded Menelaus Il. 4.193;
goes round and inspects the host and the chiefs Il. 4.223;
slays Adrestus-3 taken by Menelaus Il. 7.63;
accepts Hector's challenge, but does not get the lot Il. 6.162;
refuses the proposals of the Trojan herald except as to the burning of the dead Il. 6.406;
reproaches the Greeks retreating before Hector Il. 8.217;

calls an assembly Il. 9.9, addresses it and again counsels a return home 17, reproved by Diomedes 32, in a gathering in his hut agrees, on the suggestion of Nestor, to placate Achilles 115, an embassy is dispatched accordingly 178, but returns unsuccessful 669; A. cannot sleep (1), goes to rouse Nestor and other chiefs 17;
his ἀριστεία 15, is wounded by Coon 248, but continues to fight 255, retires 280;
with the other wounded chiefs encounters Nestor Il. 14.27, advises the launching of the ships 65, reproved by Odysseus 83, accepts the reproof 104;
his speech in the assembly on the renunciation by Achilles of his wrath Il. 19.78, his oath about Briseis 258;
receives the prize for spear-throwing without a contest Il. 23.884;
etc.: after the taking of Troy advised, opposing Menelaus, delay in returning home in order to placate Athene Od. 3.141, remained accordingly 155;
his death at the hands of Aegisthus Od. 1.32, 298, Od. 3.194, 234, 250, 303, Od. 4.519, Od. 11.384, 409, Od. 13.383, Od. 24.96 (see also Orestes-3);
in the Shades Od. 11.387, Od. 24.19; etc.
Eldest daughter of Augeias and wife of Moulius-1.
Son of Ancaeus-1 and leader of the Arcadians Il. 2.609.
Son of Augeias and father of Polyxeinus Il. 2.624.
Wounded and slain by Diomedes Il. 11.338, 368, 373.

div.head: Ἀγέλαος-3
div.p:
Counsels the
suitors to abstain from violence Od. 13.321, 339;
in the fight advises communication with the people outside Od. 22.131, 136; Od. 22.212, 241, 247.
(ἀμύμων τε κρατερός τε, ἀντίθεος, δῖος, μεγάθυμος).
Son of Antenor and father of Echeclus-1 Slays Elephenor Il. 4.467; Il. 11.59, Il. 12.93, Il. 13.490, 598, Il. 14.425;
stands up to Achilles Il. 21.545, 579, is snatched away by Apollo 595, 600.

div.head: Ἀγκαῖος-2
div.p: Nestor beat him at wrestling Il. 23.635.
Mother of Nireus by Charopos Il. 2.672.

div.head: Ἀγχίαλος-1
div.p: With his brother Menesthes killed by Hector Il. 5.609.
Son of Capys and father of Aeneas by Aphrodite;
Patronymic Ἀσιάδης. App. son of Asius-2 Il. 12.140;
wounds Antilochus and is killed by Meriones Il. 13.560, 759, 771.
Husband of Alcestis and father of Eumelus Il. 2.713, 714, Il. 23.289, 391, 532.
A plain at the mouth of the Grenicus Il. 2.828.
A handmaid of Helen at Sparta Od. 4.123.

div.head: Ἄδρηστος-1
div.p: King of Sicyon, and father of Aegialeia Il. 2.572;
father also of the wife of Tydeus (Deipyle) Il. 14.121;

div.head: Ἄδρηστος-2
div.p: Son of Merops and with his brother Amphius-1 the leader of the men of Adresteia, etc. Il. 2.830;

div.head: Ἀθηναίη-2
div.p: (ἀγελείη, (αἰγιόχοιο) Διὸς τέκος, Ἀλαλκομενηΐς, Ἀτρυτώνη, (θεὰ) γλαυκῶπις, δῖα θεάων, Διὸς ἐκγεγαρυῖα, ἐρυσίπτολις, ἠΰκμομος, θυγάτηρ Διός, κούρη Διὸς (αιγιόχοιο), κυδίστη, λαοσσόος, ληῗτις, μεγάθυμος, πολύβουλος, πότνια, Τριτογένεια.)
Daughter of Zeus (her mother not named).
Sent by Hera checks the wrath of Achilles in the assembly Il. 1.194;
sent by her to stop the flight of the Greeks Il. 2.156;
sent by Zeus to induce the Trojans to break the truce Il. 4.78;
inspires spirit into Diomedes Il. 5.1, 121, leads Ares from the fight Il. 5.35, arms herself 733, mounts the chariot of Diomedes 835, they put Ares to flight 855;
the prayer to her of the aged Trojan women Il. 7.297;
again arms herself Od. 8.384, Hera and she start for the field to aid the Greeks 392, they are stopped by Iris sent by Zeus 413;
she checks Ares in his wrath at the death of Ascalaphus Il. 15.121;
kindles fire from the head of Achilles Il. 18.203;
introduces nectar and ambrosia into his body Il. 19.349;
in the Battle of the Gods Ares attacks her Il. 21.391, she fells him with a stone 403, she knocks down Aphrodite 423;
comes to the aid of Achilles against Hector Il. 22.214, in the likeness of Deiphobus beguiles Η. 226; in the chariotrace disables Eumelus Il. 23.391;

etc. : in the likeness of Mentes appears to Telemachus Od. 1.102, urges him to go to Pylus and Sparta 284, accompanies him in the likeness of Mentor-2 Od. 2.399, her advice to him at Pylus Od. 3.14, her prayer to Poseidon 55, she returns to the ship 357;
meets Odysseus and conducts him to the city of the Phaeacians Od. 6.18;
marks Odysseus's throw of the δίσκος Od. 8.193;
in the likeness of a youth appears to O. on his landing in Ithaca Od. 13.221, reveals herself 296, they consult 372, she transforms him into a beggar 429;
she departs for Sparta Od. 13.439, where she urges Telemachus to go home and warns him of the ambush of the suitors Od. 15.10;
she appears to Odysseus and retransforms him Od. 16.155;
she transforms him back to a beggar Od. 16.454;
she suggests to Penelope to appear before the suitors Od. 18.158;
she bears the light while the arms are being removed Od. 19.33;
she appears to Odysseus while he lies in the πρόδομος Od. 13.30;
she appears in the crisis of the fight with the suitors Od. 22.205;
is advised by Zeus to make peace between the Ithacans and Odysseus and his followers Od. 24.472, stops the fight 531;
The mountain terminating the peninsula Acte running out from Chalcidice Il. 14.229.
An epithet or name of uncertain meaning (cf. Αἰήτης).
Of her island Od. 10.135, Od. 11.70, Od. 12.3.
Son of Zeus and father of Peleus Il. 21.189.

(ἄλκιμος, ἀντίθεος, Ἀρήϊος, βοὴν ἀγαθός, δαΐφρων, διογενής, ἕρκος Ἀχαιῶν, κοίρανος λαῶν, κυδάλιμος, μεγάθυμος, μέγαλήτωρ,
μέγας, πελώριος, ταχύς, Τελαμώνιος (υἱός), φαίδιμος).
Son of Telamon and leader of the men of Salamis Il. 2.557;
after Achilles the most soldierly of the Greeks Il. 2.768;
described by Helen to Priam Il. 3.225;
he and Aias-2 visited by Agamemnon in his inspection Il. 4.273;
chosen by lot to fight Hector Il. 6.181, the fight 206, they exchange gifts 303;
his brother the archer Teucrus shoots from behind his shield Il. 8.267, he rescues him when wounded 330;
is one of the embassy to Achilles Il. 9.169, makes the final appeal 622;
with Menelaus comes to the rescue of Odysseus Il. 11.465, retires panic-stricken 544;
goes with Teucrus to the help of Menestheus Il. 12.364;
makes a stand on the platforms of the ships Il. 15.674, retires to a gangway 727, abandons the ship Il. 16.102;
with Menelaus comes to the rescue of the corpse of Patroclus Il. 17.123, his cry for light 645, the corpse is at last rescued Il. 18.231;
his drawn wrestling-match with Odysseus Il. 23.708, meets Diomedes in the fight in armour 811, is second in putting the weight 838;
in the Shades Od. 11.469, avoids Odysseus 543, 550;
In dual Αἴαντε and pl. Αἴαντες (with dat. Αἰάντεσσιν) the two ὁμώνυμοι (P 720) spoken of or acting together
(θεράποντες Ἄρηος, θοῦριν ὲπιειμένοι ἀλκήν, μεμαότε θούριδος ἀλκῆς, κορυστά, πολέμου ἀκορήτω)

div.head: Αἴας-2
div.p: Son of Oieus-1 and leader of the Locrians.
recognizes a god in the guise of Calchas Il. 13.66;
stands firm with his namesake Il. 13.701;
watching the chariot-race abuses Idomeneus Il. 23.473, comes in second in the foot-race 754;
etc.: his death at the Gyraean Rock Od. 4.499, 509.
A seat of the worship of Poseidon of disputed site Od. 8.203, Il. 13.21: Od. 5.381.
A hundred-handed being called by the gods Βριάρεως.
Patronymic fr. Αἰγεύς, king of Athens.
Daughter of Adrestus-1 and wife of Diomedes Il. 5.412.

div.head: Αἰγιαλός-1
div.p: A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.575.
App. a town of Ithaca Il. 2.633.
In the realm of Diomedes Il. 2.562.
Son of Thyestes and cousin of Agamemnon and Menelaus.

Seduced Clytaemnestra and with her aid killed A. (C. killing Cassandra (Od. 11.422)) on A. 's return, all his and A. 's followers also being killed Od. 1.35, 42, 300, Od. 3.194, 198, 235, 250, 256, 263, 303, Od. 4.518, 525, 529, 537, Od. 11.389, 409, Od. 24.22, 97;
slain with Clytaemnestra by Orestes-3 Od. 1.29, 300, Od. 3.195, 198, 306, 310.

div.head: Αἰγύπτιος-1
div.p: Father of Antiphus-4 and Eurynomus Od. 2.15.
Αἴγυπτόνδε [-δε], to the N. Od. 4.483, Od. 14.246, Od. 17.426.
In fem., the land of Egypt Od. 4.351, 355, Od. 14.275, Od. 17.448.
Also genit. Ἄϊδος?̔ἆ and dat. Ἄϊδι?̔ἆ?̔ἀδάμαστος, ἀμείλιχος, ἐνέροισιν ἀνάσσων, ἴφθιμος, κλυτότωλος, κρατερός, πελώριος, πυλάρτης, στυγερός).
Hades, son of Cronus and Rhea, brother of Zeus, Poseidon, Hera and Demeter, and husband of Persephoneia.
By lot (Il. 15.187, 191) got the underworld as his realm.
Wounded by Heracles with an arrow Il. 5.395; πύλαι Ἀΐδαο Il. 5.646, Il. 9.312, Il. 23.71: Od. 14.156; Ἄϊδος κυνέη Il. 5.845;
his dog carried off by Heracles Il. 8.367, 368;
His δόμος or δόμοι, δῶ, δῶμα, see δόμος 2, δῶ 2, δῶμα 2 in Lex.
See also εἰς Π̔̓ 2, εἴσω 3, ἐκ Π̔̓ 1 in Lex.
King of Colchis, son of Eelius and Perse and brother of Circe Od. 10.137;
the voyage of the Argo from his land Od. 12.70.
Driven by Menelaus in the chariot-race Il. 23.295, 409, 525.
The Centaurs driven to their land by Peirithous Il. 2.744.
A people represented as dwelling by Ocean on the extreme limits of the world.
Zeus and the gods go thither for a sacrifice Il. 1.423;
so Iris Il. 23.206: and Poseidon Od. 1.22, Od. 5.287.
Returning from them Poseidon desries Odysseus Od. 5.282.
A handmaid of Helen at Troy Il. 3.144.

div.head: Αἴθων-2
div.p: The name assumed by Odysseus in his tale to Penelope Od. 19.183.
(ἄναξ ἀνδρῶν, ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, βονηφόος, δαΐφρων, ἐΰς, μεγάθυμος, μεγαλήτωρ, πόδας ταχύς, Τρώων ἀγός?̔βουληφόρος.)

with Pandarus
attacks Diomedes Il. 5.166, is wounded by Δ. 305, but rescued by Aphrodite 311, his horses driven off by Capaneus 319, Il. 8.108, Il. 23.292, D attacks him again Il. 5.432, but retires before Apollo 443; A. 's resentment against Priam Il. 13.459;
he meets Achilles in fight Od. 3.160, tells his parentage 199, is rescued by Poseidon 320;
The mod. Enos, a Thracian town at the mouth of the Hebrus.
Patronymic fr. Αἴολος (no doubt different from the Aeolus below; but the Aeolus legends can hardly be disentangled).
Dwelt with his sons and daughters on a floating island Od. 10.2;
made by Zeus controller of the winds Od. 10.21; Od. 10.36, 44, 60, Od. 23.314.
Adj. fr. Αἴπυτος, son of Elatus, an Arcadian Il. 2.604

div.head: Αἴσηπος-1
div.p: A river of the Troad flowing into the Propontis Il. 2.825, Il. 4.91 Il. 12.21.

div.head: Αἴσηπος-2
div.p: With his twin brother Pedasus-3 killed by Euryalus-1 Il. 7.21.
A Paeonian town, or perh. rather an unknown town of the Troad.
Son of Cretheus and Tyro Od. 11.259.
Of Aetolia, a district of Greece having the Achelous on the w., and bounded by the Gulf of Corinth on the killed by Of Thoas-1 Il. 4.527.
Of one who beguiled Eumaeus Od. 14.379.
In pl., the men of Aetolia G
their strife with the Couretes (see Κουρῆτες) Il. 9.529, 531, 549, 575, 597; Il. 13.218, Il. 15.282, Il. 23.633.

div.head: Ἀκάμας-1
div.p: A leader of the Dardanians Il. 2.823, Il. 11.60, Il. 12.100, Il. 14.476, 478, 488.

div.head: Ἀκάμας-2
div.p: A leader of the Thracians Il. 2.844, Il. 5.462.
Patronymic of Danae, daughter of Acrisius Il. 14.319.
A servant given by her father to Penelope on her marriage Od. 23.228.
In form a patr. ; but the occurrence against analogy of two such words together in Il. 11.750
(Ἀκτορίωνε Μολίονε) makes it doubtful whether it is a patr.
The words have not been satisfactorily explained.
Of Cteatus and Eurytus-2 Il. 11.750, Il. 23.638.
Of Amphimachus and Thalpius (sons of C. and E.) Il. 2.621.

div.head: Ἄκτωρ-1
div.p: Patronymic Ἀζεΐδης. App. father of Astyoche Il. 2.513.

div.head: Ἀλάστωρ-1
div.p: assists Mecisteus-2 in carrying off the wounded Teucrus Il. 8.333, and Hypsenor-2 Il. 13.422.
A plain not localized. 'A. is app. formed to agree in sound with ἀλᾶτο in the same line Il. 7.201. 'The plain of wandering.'
A hill on the confines of Bouprasion Il. 2.617, Il. 11.757.
Wife of Oeneus and mother of Tydeus and Meleagrus Il. 9.555.
A brother of A. slain by M. and her curses thereupon Il. 9.565.
Perh. a people of the killed by shore of the Euxine beyond the Paphlagonians Il. 2.856, Il. 5.39.
His speech in the assembly Od. 2.157; Od. 2.253, Od. 17.68;
Son of Aesyetes-2, husband of Hippodameia-2 and son-in-law of Anchises Il. 12.93.
Daughter of Pelies, wife of Admetus and mother of Eumelus Il. 2.715.
Son of Laerces-1 A leader under Achilles Il. 16.197;
comes to the aid of Automedon Il. 17.467, 475, 481, 500, 501.
(ὄζος Ἄρηος(. θεράπων of Achilles Il. 19.392, Il. 24.474, 574.

(ἀμύμων, βασιλεύς, δαΐθρων, θεοειδής,
θεοείκελος, θεῶν ἄπο μήδεα εἰδώς, ίερὸν μένος, κρείων, μεγαλήτωρ, πάντων ἀριδείκετος λαῶν).
Son of Nausithous, husband of Arete (the daughter of his brother Rhexenor) and father of Laodamas-2 Halius-2, Clytoneus and Nausicaa.
his house described Od. 6.84, and his orchard and garden 112; Odysseus approaches him and Arete Od. 6.141, he raises O. from the hearth 167, promises him conduct to his home 317, Od. 8.26;
entertains him with games Od. 8.97, and with the singing of Demodocus 254;
proposes the giving of gifts to him Od. 8.389;
puts the gifts on board the ship Od. 13.20, dispatches Il. 15.64 ; for fear of Poseidon proposes to give up conducting strangers Od. 13.171;
A handmaid of Helen at Sparta Od. 4.124.

Wife of Amphitryon and mother of Heracles by Zeus Il. 14.323; H 's birth delayed by contrivance of Here, whereby H. became subject to Eurystheus Il. 19.99, 119: A. brought into comparison with Penelope Od. 2.120;
A town of Argos-2 on the north shore of the entrance to the Malian Gulf Il. 2.682.
A town of Argos-2 on the west shore of the Pagasaean Gulf Il. 2.682.
King of the Leleges and father of Laothoe Il. 21.85, 86, Il. 22.51.
Odysseus in his tale to Laertes claims to have come thence Od. 24.304.
A town of the Halizonians Il. 2.857.
Peloponnesus flowing through the (app. n.) extremity of Nestor's realm Il. 2.592;
Husband of Iphimedeia and nominal father of Otus-1 and Ephialtes Il. 5.386: Od. 11.305.
Invaded Phrygia Il. 3.189; Bellerophon's fight with them Il. 7.186.
The city of the Paeonians Il. 2.849, Il. 16.288.
Son of Cretheus and Tyro Od. 11.259.
A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.584.
Ruler of Hellas (but in Il. 10.266 he is spoken of as living in Eleon) and father of Phoenix-1 Il. 9.448, Il. 10.266.
The seer, son of Oicles, husband of Eriphyle and father of Alcmaon-2 and Amphilochus.
Perished by the treachery of his wife Od. 15.244, 253.

div.head: Ἀμφιδάμας-2
div.p: His son killed in a quarrel by Patroclus Il. 23.87.
Wife of Autolycus and mother of Anticleia Od. 19.416.

div.head: Ἀμφίμαχος-1
div.p: Son of Cteatus and grandson of Poseidon, and a leader of the Epeians Il. 2.620.
Killed by Hector Il. 13.185, 189, 195, 203; Poseidon's wrath at his slaying Il. 13.206.

div.head: Ἀμφίμαχος-2
div.p: Son of Nomion and a leader of the Carians Il. 2.870, 871.
A suitor, son of Melaneus Od. 24.103; Od. 22.242;
wounds Telemachus Od. 22.277, who slays him 284;
Son of Nisus, and the leader of the suitors from Doulichium.
First sees the ship returning from the ambush laid for Telemachus Od. 16.351;
wishes Odysseus well after the fight with Irus Od. 18.119, his presentiment of evil 153, Ο. takes refuge with him when threatened by Eurymachus 395.
A divine marine being Od. 3.91, Od. 5.422, Od. 12.60, 97.
Husband of Alcmene and putative father of Heracles Il. 5.392: Od. 11.266, 270.

div.head: Ἀμφίων-1
div.p: A leader of the Epeians Il. 13.692.

div.head: Ἀμφίων-2
div.p: With his brother Zethus represented as having founded Thebes-1 Od. 11.262.

div.head: Ἀμφίων-3
div.p: King of Orchomenus-1 and father of Chloris Od. 11.283.
Daughter of Eetion-1, wife of Hector and mother of Astyanax.

Absent when H. visited his house
Il. 7.371, 377, her meeting and conversation with him 395, 405; her care of his horses Il. 8.187; Il. 17.208;
sees his corpse being dragged to the ships Il. 22.460, her lament for him and Astyanax 477;
her lament over his ransomed corpse Il. 24.723.
Daughter (app.) of a king of Lycia and wife of Proetus (see under Βελλεροφόντης) Il. 7.160.
Husband of Theano and father of Acamas-1 Agenor, Archelochus, Coon, Demoleon, Helicaon, Iphidamas, Laodocus-1, Laodamas-1, Pedaius (bastard), and Polybus-1 Il. 2.822, Il. 3.148;
had entertained Odysseus and Menelaus Il. 3.203; Il. 3.262, 312, Il. 7.299;
Daughter of Autolycus, wife of Laertes and mother of Odysseus and Ctimene.
Her death Od. 15.356; O. sees her in the Shades Od. 11.85.
(ἀγλαός, ἀμύμων, δαΐφρων, διοτρεφής, θείειν ταχύς, θοὸς πολεμιστής, κρατερός, κυδάλιμος, μαχητής, μενεχάρμης, μήστωρ ἀϋτῆς, Νηλήϊος, πεπνυμένος).
comes to the rescue of Menelaus Il. 5.565;
slays the chariot-driver of Asius-2 Il. 13.396;
hears from Menelaus of the death of Patroclus Il. 17.685, announces the death to Achilles Il. 18.18;

takes part in the chariot-race Il. 23.301, Nestor's advice to him 306, addresses his horses 402, gains the advantage of Menelaus and comes in second 417, objects to Achilles' proposal to give Eumelus the second prize 541, Menelaus accuses him of foul driving 566, A. pacifies him 586, takes part in the foot-race 756, comes in last 785;
etc.: Nestor speaks of his death at Troy Od. 3.112;
in the Shades Od. 11.468, Od. 24.16; Od. 24.78.
Father of Hippolochus-2, Peisandrus-1 and Hippomachus.
Corrupted by Paris opposed the restoration of Helen Il. 11.123, 132, 138; Il. 12.188.
With Eurymachus leader of the suitors.
Taunts Telemachus among the suitors Od. 1.383;
answers T. in the Ithacan assembly Od. 2.84;
proposes to waylay T. Od. 4.660, gets a ship ready for this 778, reports ill success Od. 16.363;
the disguised Odysseus begs from him Od. 17.414, he strikes him with a stool 458;
refrains from trial of the bow Od. 21.186 (he does not seem to make the trial at all).
Daughter of the Asopus and mother by Zeus of Amphion-2 and Zethus Od. 11.260.

div.head: Ἀντιφάτης-2
div.p: The king of the Laestrygonians Od. 10.81, 106, 114, 199.

div.head: Ἀντιφάτης-3
div.p: Son of Melampus and father of Oicles Od. 15.242, 243.
A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.250.

div.head: Ἄντιφος-1
div.p: Son of Thessalus and with his brother Pheidippus a leader of the men of Nisurus, Cos, etc., Il. 2.678.

div.head: Ἄντιφος-2.
div.p: Son of Talaemenes and a leader of the Maeonians

div.head: Ἄντιφος-3
div.p: A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 4.489;
had been taken with his brother Isus on Ida and released on ransom, now both slain by Agamemnon Il. 11.101, 104, 109.

div.head: Ἄντιφος-5.
div.p: A comrade in Ithaca of Odysseus Od. 17.68.
A town in the realm of Protesilaus Il. 2.697.
A river flowing into the Thermaic Gulf Il. 2.849, 850, Il. 16.288;
father of Pelegon by Periboea-1 Il. 21.141, 157, 158.
Dwelt by the roadside in Arisbe.
With his charioteer Calesius killed by Diomedes Il. 7.12.
A dist. of the Troad on the western extremity of the Propontis Il. 2.828, Il. 5.612.
Voc. Ἄπολλον?̔ἄναξ, ἀργυρότοξος, Δῒ φίλος, ἑκάεργος, ἑκατηβελέτης, ἑκατηβόλος, ἕκατος, ἑκηβόλος, κλυτότοξος, λαοσσόος, Λυκηγενής, χρυσάορος).
Son of Zeus and Leto and brother of Artemis.
Besought by Chryses (Il. 1.37) sends pestilence on the Greeks Il. 1.43, is appeased 457;
with Poseidon destroys the Greek wall Il. 12.17;
sent by Zeus heartens Hector Il. 15.236;
repels Patroclus from the walls Il. 16.698;
strikes and unarms P. Il. 16.788, Il. 18.454;

his death-dealing shafts (always directed against men, for those of Artemis see Ἄρτεμις) Il. 21.278, Il. 24.605, 758 (cf. Od. 3.279, Od. 6.64, Od. 15.410, Od. 17.251, 494); in the Battle of the Gods Poseidon challenges him Il. 21.436, but he declines 461;
beguiles Achilles while the Trojans flee Il. 21.599; Achilles destined to fall before him and Paris Il. 22.359;
in the chariot-race disables Diomedes Il. 23.382;
A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.571.
The people of Argos-1 (1) Il. 19.122, 124: Od. 3.309, Od. 15.240.
The people of Proetus (his seat being Tiryns in Argos-1 (1)) Il. 7.159.
The Greeks on their way to Troy Od. 1.211, Od. 2.173, Od. 18.253, Od. 19.126.
The Greeks in the field at Troy
The Greeks preparing for or on their return
Its men led by Polypoetes and Leonteus Il. 2.738.

The Argolic plain in the Peloponnesus stretching inwards from the Argolic gulf, and, app., adjoining lands Il. 1.30, Il. 2.108 (here app. the whole of the mainland over which Agamemnon's sway extended), 115, 559 (the realm of Diomedes (cf. Il. 7.224, Il. 14.119: Od. 3.180)), Il. 4.171, Il. 7.224, Il. 9.22, 141, 283, Il. 13.379, Il. 14.119, Il. 15.30, Il. 19.115: Od. 3.180, 251, 263, Od. 15.224, 239, 274.
The city Argos still known by the same name Il. 4.52: Od. 21.108.
Of southern Greece, esp. the Pelopnnesus, in contrast to northern Greece Il. 7.152: Od. 4.174, 562.
Esp. in phrase καθ̓?̔ἀν̓ Ἑλλάδα καὶ μέσον Ἄργος 344, Od. 4.726, 816, Od. 15.80.
App. also Il. 3.75, 258 (Argos and Achaeis being app. to be regarded as the same).

div.head: Ἄργος-2
div.p: Πελασγικόν. App. a general name for the realm of Peleus, including Phthia and Hellas Il. 2.681.

div.head: Ἄργος-3.
div.p: The only creature to recognize O. in his disguise Od. 17.292, 300;
The ship of the Argonauts Od. 12.70.
A spring in Ithaca near the dwelling of Eumaeus and the Κόρακος πέτρη 408.

div.head: Ἀρηΐθοος-1
div.p: Father by Phylomedousa of Menesthius-1 Il. 6.8, 10;
A town of Pylus Il. 2.591, Il. 11.723.

(ἀΐδηλος, ἀλλοπρόσαλλος, ἀνδροφόνος, ἆτος πολέμοιο, βριήπυος, βροτολοιγός, ἐγχέσπαλος, θοός, θοῦρος, κορυθαίολος, κρατερός, λαοσσόος, μιαιφόνος, ὄβριμος, ὀξύς, οὖλος, πελώριος, πτολίπορθος, ῥινοτόρος, ταλαύρινος πολεμιστής, τειχεσιπλήτης, χάλκεος, χρυσήνιος).
Son of Zeus and Her and father by Astyoche of Ascalaphus and Ialmenus.
Athene leads him from the fray Il. 5.30; Aphrodite begs the use of his horses Il. 5.355;
had been put in bonds by Otus-1 and Ephialtes Il. 5.385; Athene and Diomedes go against him Il. 5.840, D. wounds him and puts him to flight 855, his complaint to Zeus 872, he is cured 899;
his rage on hearing of the death of Ascalaphus Il. 15.113, restrained by Athene 125;
in the Battle of the Gods attacks Athene Il. 21.391, who lays him low 403, Aphrodite leads him off 416, Ath. lays them both low 423;
Daughter of Rhexenor and niece and wife of Alcinous.
Her parentage Od. 6.54, how she was honoured by A. and the people 67; Odysseus supplicates her Od. 6.142;
she recognizes the robe given to O. by Nausicaa Od. 6.233;
Her dancing-floor at Cnosus Il. 18.592: carried off by Theseus but slain by Artemis in Dia Od. 11.321.
A mythical people in whose country Typhoeus was put in bonds by Zeus Il. 2.783.

A town of the Troad between
A bydus and Percote Il. 2.836, Il. 7.13, Il. 21.43.
The swift horse of Adrestus-1 of divine origin Il. 23.346.
The Arcadians, an inland people of central Peloponnesus, to whom Agamemnon furnished ships Il. 2.611; Il. 6.134.
The country of the Arcadians Il. 2.603.
A leader of the Boeotians Il. 2.495.
The real name of Irus Od. 18.5.
The fountain of the Laestrygonians Od. 10.108.
(ἁγνή, ἀγροτέρη, ἐϋπλόκαμος, ἰοχέαιρα, κελαδεινή, πότνα θεά, χρυσηλάκατος, χρυσήνιος, χρυσόθρονος).
Daughter of Zeus and Leto and sister of Apollo Il. 5.51, 53, 447, Il. 7.205;

her death-dealing shafts, always (except Od. 5.123) directed against women (those of Apollo against men) Il. 7.428, Il. 19.59, Il. 24.606 (cf. Od. 11.172, 324, Od. 15.410, 478, Od. 18.202, Od. 20.60, 61, 80); Il. 9.533, Il. 16.183, Od. 3.39, 71;
in the Battle of the Gods reproaches Apollo Il. 21.471, Hera assaults her 489: Od. 4.122, Od. 7.102, 151, Od. 17.37, Od. 19.54, Od. 20.71.
A Sidonian, father of the Phoenician woman who stole Eumaeus away Od. 15.426.
A leader of the Dardanians Il. 2.823, Il. 12.100.
Hector takes him as his chariot-driver Il. 8.128.
And app. of Adamas Il. 12.140, Il. 13.561, 759, 771.
A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.560.

div.head: Ἄσιος-1
div.p: Son of Dymas-1 full brother of Hecabe and uncle of Hector.

div.head: Ἄσιος-2
div.p: Son of Hyrtacus and father of Phaenops-3.
Leader of the men of Percote, Abydus, etc. Il. 2.837, 838, Il. 12.95, 96;
eagerly attacks the Greeks at the ships Il. 12.110, 136, 139, 163.

div.head: Ἄσιος-3
div.p: Adj. fr., the second form genit. of, Ἀσίας, said to have been a king of Lydia Il. 2.461.
A leader of the men of Orchomenus-1, etc. Il. 2.512, Il. 9.82, Il. 13.478.
A lake (and its district) connected with the Propontis, on which lake lay the later town of Nicaea Il. 2.863, Il. 13.793.
Came from Ascania, son of Hippotion.
A leader of the Phrygians Il. 2.862, Il. 13.792.
Father of Podaleirius and Machaon Il. 2.731, Il. 4.194, Il. 11.518.
A Boeotian town near Orchomenus-1 Il. 2.511.
Son of Tros-1, father of Capys and grandfather of Anchises Od. 3.232, 239.
Its men led by Eurypylus-2 Il. 2.735.
An island represented as lying between Ithaca and Same Od. 4.846.
Son of Pelegon and a leader of the Paeonians Il. 12.102, Il. 17.217, 351, 352.
Infant son of Hector and Andromache (called Scamandrius by his father).
Captured by Heracles at Ephyre-1 and bore him Tlepolemus-1 Il. 2.658.
Daughter (app.) of Actor-1 and mother by Ares of Ascalaphus and Ialmenus Il. 2.513.
θεράπων of Menelaus at Sparta Od. 4.216.
A river of killed by Boeotia Il. 4.383, Il. 10.287: father of Antiope Od. 11.260.

Son of Pelops, brother of Thyestes and father of
Agamemnon and Menelaus Il. 2.23;
the sceptre given to him by Pelops and by him to Thyestes Il. 2.105, 106; Il. 3.37, Il. 7.46, Il. 17.1;
Son of Amisodarus and brother of Maris.

div.head: Αὐγειαί-2
div.p: A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.583.
Ruler of Elis and father of Agasthenes and Agamede.
A Boeotian town on the Euripus by which the Greek ships assembled Il. 2.303, 496.
Husband of Amphithee and father of Anticleia Od. 11.85;
gives a name to the babe Odysseus, his grandson Od. 19.399; O. goes to visit him and is wounded by a boar Od. 19.413, Od. 21.220, Od. 24.334.
His skill in thieving and false swearing Il. 10.267: Od. 19.394.
Son of Diores-2. θεράπων of Achilles Il. 9.209, Il. 16.864;
acts as chariot-driver to Patroclus Il. 16.145, 148, 219, 472, 684;
after P. 's death drives alone Il. 17.429, 452, 459;
stands up to Hector and Aeneas Il. 17.483, 498;
acts as chariot-driver to Achilles Il. 19.392, 397; Il. 23.563, Il. 24.474, 574, 625.
Alleged father of the alleged Eperitus Od. 24.305.
(ἆ?̔δῖα, Διὸς θυγάτηρ?̔κούρἠ, ἐϋστέφανος, φιλομμειδής, χρυσέη, χρυσείη).
Daughter of Zeus and Dione and by Anchises mother of Aeneas (Il. 2.820).
In Od. (Od. 8.266) the wife of Hephaestus.
carries off Aeneas from Diomedes Il. 5.311, D. attacks and wounds her 330, her complaint to Dione 370;
in the Battle of the Gods leads off the wounded Ares Il. 21.416, is smitten by Athene 423;
etc.: Od. 4.14, 261; Demodocus's tale of Ares and Aphrodite Od. 8.266, 308, 337, 342, 362; Od. 17.37, Od. 19.54, Od. 20.68, 73.
The women of the realm of Odysseus
Fem. adj. (1) Achaean. Ἀχαιῒς γαῖα?̔αἶἀ Ἀχαιός 2.b (a)) Il. 1.254, Il. 6.124: Od. 13.249, Od. 21.107.
(καλλιγύναιξ) Il. 3.75, 258 (for these cf. under Ἄργος-1 (4)): Od. 11.166, 481, Od. 23.68.
App. in particular of the realm of Peleus
In pl., (the) Achaean women Il. 2.235, Il. 6.96.
App. in particular of the maidens of the realm of Peleus Il. 9.395: of the realm of Odysseus Od. 21.251.
In sing., of the Achaeans (see (2) (b) (g) below) Il. 3.167, 226.
Applied with Μυρμιδόνες and Ἕλληνες to the followers of Achilles Il. 2.684.
(ἀρήϊοι, ἀρηΐφιλοι, δῖοι, ἑλίκωπες, ἐϋκνήμιδες, κάρη κομόωντες, μεγάθυμοι, μένεα πνείοντες, μένος ἄσχετοι, ὑπερκύδαντες, φιλοπτόλεμοι, χαλκοχίτωνες, χαλκοκνήμιδες).
The followers of Odysseus on his way to Troy (in O.'s tale to Penelope) Od. 19.199.
The Greeks in the field at Troy
The Greeks preparing for and on their return
The people of Neleus or Nestor at Pylus Il. 11.759: Od. 3.372.
The ruling race in Argos-1 (1) (3) Od. 15.274, Od. 18.246.
Said by Odysseus in his tale to Penelope to be one of the five divisions of the inhabitants of Crete Od. 19.175.

div.head: Ἀχελώϊος-1
div.p: The largest Greek river flowing south from the Pindus range to the Ionian Sea Il. 21.194.

div.head: Ἀχελώϊος-2.
div.p: An unknown river of Lydia Il. 24.616.
A river of the underworld Od. 10.513.

(ἀγαυός, ἀμύμων, ἄναξ, Ἀρήϊος, δαΐφρων, διίφιλος, δῖος, θεῖος, θεοείκελος, θεοῖς ἐπιείκελος, θυμολέων, κλυτός, καρτερός, κυδάλιμος, μεγάθυμος, μέγα φέρτατος Ἀχαιῶν, ἄβριμος, ὀλοός, ὄρχαμος ἀνδρῶν, πελώριος, ποδάρκης, πόδας ταχύς?̔ὠκύς̓, ποδώκης, ποιμὴν λαῶν, πτολίπορθος, ῥηξήνωρ, ταχύς, ὑπέρθυμος, φαίδιμος, ὠκύς).
Son of Peleus and Thetis and father of Neoptolemus.
Leader of the Myrmidons and the great bulwark of the Greeks.

Calls an assembly Il. 1.54, addresses Agamemnon 59, and Calchas 85, A. again 122, abuses A. 149, questions with himself whether to slay A. 188, Athene appears 194, and restrains him 207, he abuses A. again 225, his final speech to A. 293, retires to his ships from the fight 306;
yields Briseis to the heralds of Agamemnon Il. 1.337, calls to his mother 352, she promises her intercession with Zeus 414;

he receives the embassy Il. 9.193, his speech 308, he rejects finally the proposals 644; Patroclus approaches him Il. 16.2, and asks to be sent to the fight 21, Achilles accedes 49, and marshals the Myrmidons 155, his prayer to Zeus 233;

he hears from Antilochus of the death of Patroclus Il. 18.18, his mother comes to him 70, and promises armour from Hephaestus 136; Iris urges him to come to the rescue of the corpse of Patroclus Il. 18.170, Athene kindles fire from his head 203, he shouts from the ditch 215, and accompanies the rescued corpse 234, his lament 316;
his mother brings the divine armour Il. 19.8, he rouses the host 40, he renounces his wrath 146;
he assumes the armour Il. 19.367, and addresses his horses 400;

he and Aeneas meet in fight Od. 3.158, Poseidon withdraws Aeneas 325; Achilles and Hector meet Od. 3.422, Apollo withdraws Η. 443, Achilles does much execution 455; he drives a part of the foe into the Xanthus-1 Il. 21.7, he encounters Lycaon-2 34, and slays him 116, after doing much execution is addressed by the river 214, the river rises upon him 240, he is saved by the fire of Hephaestus 342; Agenor stands up to him 550, is withdrawn by Apollo 596, Apollo in his guise beguiles Achilles to a vain pursuit 599;

he approaches the city Il. 22.21, Hector awaits him 35, but flees before him and is chased thrice round the walls 136, they fight 273, Achilles slays Η. 326, and drags the corpse to the ships 395; the shade of Patroclus appears to him Il. 23.65, he places his lock dedicated to the Spercheius in the hands of P.'s corpse 140, he summons the winds to fan the pyre 192;

he sets the prizes for the funeral games Il. 23.262; Thetis sent by Zeus persuades him to accept ransom for Hector's corpse from Priam Il. 24.128, he hearkens to P.'s appeal 483, he gives directions for releasing the corpse 572;
his strife with Odysseus Od. 8.75; O. encounters him in the Shades Od. 11.467, 478, 482, 486, his lament to Odysseus 488; Od. 11.546, 557;
One of the horses of Achilles, by Zephyrus out of Podarge Il. 16.149, Il. 19.400.
A hill in the Trojan plain Il. 2.813.
So called by mortals; called by the gods (Il. 2.814) the grave-mound of Myrine.
Son of Glaucus-1 and father of Isandrus, Hippolochus-1 and Laodameia.

repulsed the love of Anteia, wife of Proetus Il. 7.160, by her contrivance sent by P. to P.'s father-in-law the king of Lycia with a secret message importing his death 163, the dangerous tasks set him 178, and the ambush laid for him 187, received the king's daughter to wife and half of the kingdom 191, his children 196, his fate 200;
had been entertained by Oeneus Il. 7.216, 220.

div.head: Βίας-3
div.p: Father of Laogonus-2 and Dardanus-2 Od. 3.460.
With his comrade Oileus-2 killed by Agamemnon Il. 11.92.
A town of the realm of Eumelus lying on the Boebean Lake (see next) Il. 2.712.
A lake lying west of and under the range of Pelion and Ossa Il. 2.711.
The original home of Epeigeus Il. 16.572.
Bastard son of Laomedon and father by Abarbaree of Aesepus-2 and Pedasus-3 (twins) Il. 7.22, 23.
A region of Elis Il. 2.615, Il. 11.756, 760;
the scene of the funeral of Amarynceus Il. 23.631.
Captured by Achilles at Lyrnessus Il. 2.689; Il. 1.184;
taken from A. by Agamemnon's heralds Il. 1.323, 336, 346, Il. 9.106;
her lament over Patroclus Il. 19.282; Il. 24.676.
A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.583.

div.head: Βῶρος-2.
div.p: Son of Perieres, husband of Polydore and nominal father of Menesthius-2 Il. 16.177.
Carried off by the gods to be their cup-bearer Il. 5.266, Od. 3.232.
The south west point of Euboea Od. 3.177.
Adj. from (app.) the name of an unknown place, said to have been in Elis and to have sheltered Nestor when an exile from Pylus.
A gigantic and savage race, represented (Od. 6.206) as being with the Cyclopes near the gods.

div.head: Γλαῦκος-1
div.p: Son of Sisyphus, father of Bellerophon and grandfather of Hippolochus-1 Il. 7.154, 155.

div.head: Γλαῦκος-2
div.p: Comrade of Sarpedon and a leader of the Lycians Il. 2.876;
fights Diomedes Il. 7.119, they exchange arms 234; Il. 6.13, Il. 12.102, 309, 310, 329;
the wounded Sarpedon appeals to him Il. 16.492, 508, he cries to Apollo 514, and is cured 527, 530; slays Bathyclees Il. 16.593, 597;
A town of the realm of Eumelus, prob. lying by the Boebean Lake Il. 2.712.
A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.573.
A city of Crete Il. 2.646 : part of the fleet of Menelaus wrecked near it Od. 3.294.
Leader of the Enienes and Peraebians Il. 2.748.
A river of the Troad west of the Aesepus-1 Il. 12.21.
A lake to the north of Sardis.
To Talaemenes bore Mesthles and Antiphus-2 Il. 2.865, Od. 3.391.
A rock of unknown site on which Aias-2 was destroyed by Poseidon Od. 4.500.
Its men led by Polypoetes and Leonteus Il. 2.738.
Mother of Perseus-1 by Zeus Il. 14.319.
The Greeks in the field at Troy
A district occupying the middle valley of the Scamander.
πύλαι Δαρδάνιαι, one of the gates of Troy, not identified Il. 5.789, Il. 22.194, 413.

div.head: Δάρδανος-1.
div.p: Son of Zeus, father of Erichthonius, grandfather of Tros-1 and great-grandfather of Ilus-1 Od. 3.215, 219;
the favourite child of Zeus Od. 3.304.
Priest of Hephaestus, app. at Troy.
Father of Phegeus and Idaeus-2 Il. 5.9, 27.

div.head: Δευκαλίων-1
div.p: Son of Minos and father of Idomeneus Il. 13.451, 452 : in Odysseus's tale to Penelope he says that he was D. 's son Od. 19.180, 181.

Son of Priam and Hecabe Il. 12.94, Il. 13.156, 162, 258, 402, 413, 446, 455, 490, 517, 527, 758, 770, 781; Athene takes his form in approaching Hector in
his last fight Il. 22.277; Il. 22.233, 294, 298, Il. 24.251: accompanied Helen when she visited the Trojan horse Od. 4.276;
when the city was taken Odysseus and Menelaus proceeded to his house Od. 8.517.
The Aegean island, sacred to Apollo Od. 7.162.
Daughter of Cronus and Rhea, sister of Zeus, Hades, Poseidon and Here, and mother by Zeus of Persephoneia.
the love of Zeus for her Il. 14.326;
his tale of Ares and Aphrodite Od. 8.266; Od. 8.472, 478, 483, 486, 487, 537, Od. 13.28.
A small island (now Standia) off the north coast of Crete Od. 11.325.
Son of Ortilochus-3 and father of Crethon and Ortilochus-4; dwelt at Pherae-2 Il. 5.542, 547, 548: Telemachus and Peisistratus pass the night in his house Od. 3.488, Od. 15.186.
Captured by Achilles at Lesbos Il. 9.665.

(ἀγαθός, Αἰτωλός (see Οἰνεύς), ἄλκιμος, Ἀρήϊος, ἄριστος Ἀχαιῶν, βοήν ἀγαθός, δαΐφρων, δῖος, δουρικλειτός, δουρικλυτός, ἱππόδαμος, καρτερόθυμος, κρατερός, μεγάθυμος, μενοπτόλεμος, ποιμὴν λαῶν, ὑπέρθυμος).
Son of Tydeus and husband of Aegialeia (who was his aunt, her sister (Deipyle) being the wife of Tydeus.
Leader of the men owning his sway in Argos-1 (1) Il. 2.563, 567;
visited by Agamemnon in his inspection Il. 4.365, reproves Sthenelus-1 411;

his feats under Athene's protection Il. 5.1, wounded by Pandarus 95, P. aims at him again 280, he slays Ρ. 290, attacks and wounds Aphrodite 330, 335, attacks Aeneas 432, but retires before Apollo 443, Ares attacks him 849, he wounds Ares and drives him off 855; fights Glaucus-2 Il. 7.119, they exchange arms 235;
accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 6.163;
speaks against accepting the offer of the Trojan herald Il. 6.399;
comes to the rescue of Nestor Il. 8.91, he and N. are put to flight by a thunderbolt from Zeus 130;
declares in the Assembly that he will fight to the end Il. 9.31;
his speech on the announcement by Odysseus of the result of the embassy Il. 9.697;

wakened by Agamemnon Il. 10.150, offers to penetrate the hostile lines 219, sets out with Odysseus 272, they encounter and capture and slay Dolon 339, they do execution and slay Rhesus-1 482, and return safely 540;
strikes Hector Il. 11.349, is wounded by Paris 369;
takes part in the chariot-race Il. 23.290, is disabled by Apollo 383, but comes in first 499, meets Aias-1 in the fight in armour 812;
etc.: his return from Troy Od. 3.167, 181;
in ambush in the Trojan horse Od. 4.280.
He and his attendants scattered by Lycourgus-1 Il. 7.132, 135: his part in the death of Ariadne Od. 11.325; Od. 24.74.
A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.251.
Mother by Zeus of Aphrodite Il. 5.370, 381.

div.head: Διώρης-1
div.p: Son of Amarynceus and a leader of the Epeians Il. 2.622.
Patronymic Ἰασίδης-2. Odysseus's name for an alleged king of Cyprus Od. 17.443.

div.head: Δολίος-1
div.p: A bondman of Penelope given to her by her father and in charge of the garden and orchard Od. 4.735, Od. 24.222;
he and his sons welcome Odysseus Od. 24.397, 409, 411;
a son reports the approach of the Ithacans Od. 24.492, D. arms 498.

div.head: Δολίος-2.
div.p: Father of Melanthius-1 Od. 17.212, Od. 22.159, and Melantho Od. 18.322.
A people on the west borders of the realm of Peleus Il. 9.484.
Priest of the Scamander and father of Hypsenor-1 Il. 5.77.
undertakes to Hector to penetrate the Greek lines Il. 10.319, captured by Diomedes 369, gives information 412, south Δ. 454; etc.
An island not identified the men from which were led by Meges Il. 2.625.
In Od. associated with Same, Zacynthus and Ithaca Od. 1.246, Od. 9.24, Od. 16.123, 247, Od. 19.131.
In Odysseus's tale to Eumaeus Od. 14.335, to Penelope Od. 19.292.
A leader of the Epeians Il. 13.692.

div.head: Δρύας-1
div.p: A warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.263.

div.head: Δύμας-1.
div.p: Father of Asius-1 and Hecabe Il. 16.718.

div.head: Δύμας-2
div.p: Athene takes the form of his daughter in Nausicaa's dream Od. 7.22.
In Epeirus with an oracle of Zeus (but (Il. 2.750) the Thessalian Enienes and Peraebians are said to have dwelt about it).
The prayer of Achilles to Zeus of Dodona Il. 16.234: its oak and Odysseus's consultation Od. 14.327, Od. 19.296.
In Odysseus's tale to Penelope one of the five divisions of the inhabitants of Crete Od. 19.177.
A town of Pylus where the Muses took from Thamyris his power of song Il. 2.594.
Encounters Menelaus in Pharos Od. 4.366, her advice to him 371, how he carried it out 431.
Daughter of Dymas-1, full sister of Asius-1 and wife of Priam (for her children see under Πρίαμος) Il. 7.251;
collects the aged women to pray to Athene Il. 7.286, her gift to Α. 288, 293; Il. 7.451, Il. 16.718;
vainly beseeches Hector to take refuge from Achilles Il. 22.79; Il. 22.234;
she sees H. 's corpse being dragged away Il. 22.405, her lament 430;
summoned by Priam Il. 24.193, she tries to dissuade him from going to the ships 200, she speeds him on his way 283;
her lament over Hector's ransomed, corpse Il. 24.747.
Given to Nestor when Tenedos was sacked.
Doing service in N. 's hut Il. 11.624, Il. 14.6.
Of or pertaining to Hector Il. 2.416, Il. 10.46, Il. 24.276, 579.

(ἀνδροφόνος, βοὴν ἀγαθός, βροτολοιγῷ ἶσος Ἄρηϊ, Διὶ μῆτιν ἀτάλαντος, διίφιλος, δῖος, θοῷ ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, θρασύς, ἱππόδαμος, κλυτός,?̔μέγας̓ κορυθαίολος, κρατερὸς μήστωρ φόβοιο, μεγάθυμος, μέγας, ὄβριμος, πελώριος, ποιμὴν λαῶν, φαίδιμος, φλογὶ εἴκελος ἀλκήν, χαλκοκορυστής).
Son of Priam and Hecabe and father of Astyanax.
The leader of the Trojans Il. 2.816;

reproaches Paris for shrinking from Menelaus Il. 3.38, proposes a duel between P. and Il. 12.86; Sarpedon reproaches him for neglecting the allies Il. 5.471, he leads the fight 590, the wounded Sarpedon appeals to him in vain 684, he does much execution 703; Helenus-1 advises him to retire to the city and collect the aged women to pray to Athene Il. 7.77, he goes 116, he encounters the Trojan wives 237, and his mother, whom he charges to collect the aged women 251, he proceeds to the house of Paris and reproaches him 313, his conversation with Helen 343, he proceeds to his own house but does not find Andromache there 370, he encounters her with Astyanax on his way back 392, their conversation 405, he leaves her 494, and encounters Paris returning also to the field 514, they join in the fight Il. 6.1;

he proposes a duel between himself and a Greek champion Il. 6.67, Aias-1 meets him 206, the fight broken off by the heralds 279, H. and A. exchange arms 303; H. comes to attack Nestor Il. 8.87, who is rescued by Diomedes 99; H. urges the Trojans on Il. 8.173, and addresses his horses 185, he hems in the Greeks 213, disables Teucrus 320, drives the Greeks to the ships 337;
after sunset summons an assembly Il. 8.485, advises his people to bivouac on the field 497;
he induces Dolon to go as a scout to the ships Il. 10.303, 314;

in the morning leads his people to the fight Il. 11.56, Zeus withdraws him 163, and sends Iris to advise him to refrain while Agamemnon is in the field 186, when A. is disabled leads his people on 284, is struck by Diomedes and retires 349, but with Cebriones renews the fight 521, Il. 12.40;

his horses refuse the ditch Il. 12.50, on the advice of Poulydamas advances on foot 80, an unfavourable omen 200 does not deter him 231, 251, he leads an attack on the wall 438, and breaks down the gate with a stone 445;

he leads the fight within the wall Il. 13.136, Il. 14.388, Aias-1 disables him with a stone Il. 14.409; Apollo sent by Zeus restores his strength and he renews the fight Il. 15.244, 262, lays hold of the ship of Protesilaus 704, and calls for fire 718; the ship set on fire Il. 16.122;

after he has retreated to the Scaean gate Apollo in the guise of Asius-1 urges him back to the fight Il. 16.721, he gives the final blow to Patroclus 818, urged by Apollo in the guise of Mentes-1 he joins the fight round the corpse of P. Il. 17.75, he strips the corpse 122, 125, and assumes the armour 188, Apollo in the guise of Phaenops-3 urges him on 582;
the corpse is rescued by the Greeks Il. 18.231;
he spurns the advice of Poulydamas to retire to the city Il. 18.285;
on the advice of Apollo shrinks from Achilles Od. 3.379, but advances to meet him on seeing the wounded Polydorus-1 419, Apollo snatches H. away 443;

he awaits Achilles under the walls in spite of the entreaty of his father Il. 22.35, and of his mother 79, he flees before Α. 136, Athene in the guise of Deiphobus beguiles him 226, Achilles wounds him fatally 326, his dying speech 356; A. drags his corpse to the ships Il. 22.395;

he drags the corpse thrice daily round the grave-mound of Patroclus Il. 24.14; Priam bears the ransomed corpse to the city Il. 24.689, the lament of Andromache 725, of Hecabe 748, of Helen 762, the funeral 785;
(Ἀργείη, δῖα γυναικῶν, Διὸς ἐκγεγαυῖ, εὐπατέρεια, ἠΰκομος, καλλίκομος, καλλιπάρῃος, κούρη Διός, λευκώλενος, ῥιγεδανή, τανύπεπλος).
Daughter of Leda by Zeus (nominally by Tyndareus), wife of Menelaus (but carried off by Paris) and mother by M. of Hermione-1.

Summoned by Iris to the walls to view the duel between Paris and Menelaus Il. 3.121, the Trojan elders see her and what they said 146, she names the Greek leaders to Priam 161, cannot see her brothers Castor-1 and Polydeuces 234;
summoned by Aphrodite to Paris Il. 3.383; Hector finds her with P. Il. 7.323, her conversation with Η. 343; her lament over H. Il. 24.761;
etc.: Hermione-1 her only child Od. 4.12;
her conversation at Sparta with Menelaus and Peisistratus Od. 4.121, her soothing drug 219, she tells how Odysseus came disguised to Troy 235;
her gift to Telemachus on his departure Od. 15.100, her speech to him 123; Penelope on her infatuation Od. 23.218;
Son of Antenor and husband of Laodice-1 Il. 3.123.
A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.575;
a seat of the worship of Poseidon Il. 8.203.
Part of the realm of Peleus, the valley of the Spercheius Il. 2.683, Il. 9.395, 447, 478, Il. 16.595: Od. 11.496.
Of northern in contrast to southern Greece, in phrase καθ̓?̔ἀν̓ Ἑλλάδα καὶ μέσον Ἄργος.
Applied with Μυρμιδόνες and Ἀχαιοί to the followers of Achilles Il. 2.684.

div.head: Ἕλος-1
div.p: A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.584.
A comrade of Odysseus in his ship.
Killed by mishap at Circe's house Od. 10.552;
his shade begs for funeral rites Od. 11.51, 57;
A people of northern Thessaly led by Gouneus Il. 2.749.
A river of Thessaly rising in Mt. Othrys and flowing into the Peneius Od. 11.238, 240.

div.head: Ἔννομος-1
div.p: A leader of the Mysians Il. 2.858, Il. 17.218.
A female counterpart of Ares (Euyalius) Il. 5.333, 592.
A warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.264.
A Myrmidon, son of Agaclees Il. 16.571.
Came as a suppliant to Peleus and Thetis Il. 16.573.
is last in putting the weight Il. 23.838, 839: made the Trojan horse Od. 8.493, Od. 11.523.
The name assumed by Odysseus in his tale to Laertes Od. 24.306.
A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.561.
Her incestuous marriage and suicide Od. 11.271.

div.head: Ἐπίστροφος-1
div.p: With his brother Schedius-1 leader of the men of Phocis Il. 2.517.

div.head: Ἐπίστροφος-2
div.p: Son of Euenus and brother of Munes Il. 2.692.

div.head: Ἐπίστροφος-3.
div.p: A leader of the Halizonians Il. 2.856.
Genit. Ἐρέβευς Il. 8.368: Od. 11.37. Abl. Ἐρέβεσφιν Il. 9.572.
The underworld, the realm of Hades Il. 8.368, Il. 9.572, Il. 16.327: Od. 10.528, Od. 11.37, 564, Od. 12.81.
A people, otherwise unknown, visited by Menelaus Od. 4.84.
An Arcadian slain in the armour of Areithous-1 (given to him by Lycourgus-2 (Il. 6.137, 149)) by Nestor in his youth Il. 4.319, Il. 6.136, 154.
An autochthonous hero of Athens Il. 2.547: Od. 6.81.
Bribed by a golden necklace persuaded A. to take part in the expedition of the Seven against Thebes Od. 11.326, Od. 15.247.

Son of Dardanus-1, father of
Tros-1, and grandfather of Ilus-1, Assaracus and Ganymedes Od. 3.219, 230.
Wife of Oileus-1, mother of Aias-2 and stepmother of Medon-1 Il. 13.697, Il. 15.336.
An eminence above the city of Ithaca Il. 16.471.
(ἀκάκητα, ἄναξ, ἀργεϊφόντης, διάκτορος?̔ἀ?̓, ἐΰσκοπος ἀ., κρατὺς ἀ., δώτωρ ἑάων, ἐριούνης, ἐριούνιος, Κυλλήνιος, σῶκος, χρυσόρραπις).
Son of Zeus and Maia, and father of Eudorus by Polymele.
The sceptre given by him to Pelops Il. 2.104;
sent by Zeus to conduct Priam to the ships Il. 24.334, rouses P. and urges him to return 679;
etc. : sent by Z. to bid Calypso let Odysseus go Od. 5.28, his conversation with Il. 14.85;
meets Ο. on his way to Circe's house Od. 10.277;
conducts the souls of the suitors to the Shades Od. 24.1;

div.head: Ἑρμιόνη-1
div.p: Only child of Menelaus and Helen Od. 4.14.

div.head: Ἑρμιόνη-2.
div.p: A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.560.
A river flowing near Sardis and into the Aegean Od. 3.392.
Prob. cliffs bordering Cape Carambis in Paphlagonia Il. 2.855.
A mountain range in northwest Peloponnesus Od. 7.103.
King of Thebes-1, son of Oedipodes and Epicaste Il. 4.386.
Etymologically, 'the true Cretans.' In Odysseus's tale to Penelope applied to one of the five divisions of the inhabitants of Crete Od. 19.176.
Patronymic Βοηθοΐδης. θεράπων of Menelaus at Sparta Od. 4.22, 31, Od. 15.95.:
Father of Eurypylus-2 Il. 2.736, Il. 5.79, Il. 6.167, Il. 8.265, Il. 11.575.
the home of the Abantes Il. 2.536: Od. 3.174; Od. 6.321 (see Ῥαδάμανθυς, Τιτυός).
Father of Munes and Epistrophus-2 Il. 2.693.
Athene directs O. to go to his dwelling Od. 13.404;
the dwelling described Od. 14.5, receives Ο. 29; O. tells him his tale Od. 14.192;
he tells O. his tale Od. 15.403;
is dispatched to tell Penelope of T. 's safe arrival 130, returns 452;
accompanies O. to the town Od. 17.200, they encounter Melantheus 212, they reach the city 260;
he enters O.'s house first Od. 17.324;
leaves the house to return to his own Od. 17.604;
sets down the bow etc. before the suitors for the contest Od. 21.80, O. tests him 188, he pledges himself to support Il. 15.203, O. reveals himself 207;
he carries the bow to O. that O. may take part in the contest Od. 21.359;
during the fight he and Philoetius seize Melantheus in the θάλαμος Od. 22.178, ranges himself by O. for the final fight 201, slays Elatus-2 267, is wounded by Ktesippus 279, slays Polybus-5 284;
takes part in the slaying of the unfaithful maids Od. 22.454;
accompanies O. to the country Od. 23.366;
at Laertes) house when O. comes to it Od. 24.363, prepares to fight the oncoming suitors 497, but Athene stops the fight 528;
Son of Admetus and Alcestis and husband of Iphthime.
Leader of the men of Phe=rae, etc. Il. 2.714;
his fine horses reared by Apollo Il. 2.764;
takes part in the chariot-race Il. 23.289, his chariot disabled by Athene 391, comes in last 532, but is awarded an extra prize 558;
Sent wine to the Greeks from Lemnos Il. 6.468;
leads a section of the Ithacans to attack Odysseus Od. 24.422, 465, 469, killed by Laertes 523; etc.

div.head: Εὐρύαλος-1
div.p: Son of Mecisteus-1 and companion of Diomedes Il. 2.565;
slays Dresus, Opheltius-1, Aesepus-2 and Pedasus-3 Il. 7.20;
beaten in boxing by Epeius Il. 23.677.

div.head: Εὐρύαλος-2
div.p: The fairest after Laodamas-2 Od. 8.115; Od. 8.127, 140;
taunts Odysseus Od. 8.158, they are reconciled 396, 400.

div.head: Εὐρυβάτης-1
div.p: Sent with Talthybius to bring away Briseis Il. 1.320.

div.head: Εὐρυβάτης-2
div.p: A herald who accompanied Odysseus to Troy Il. 2.184, Il. 9.170: Od. 19.247.

div.head: Εὐρυδάμας-1
div.p: Father of A bas and Polyidus-1 Il. 5.149.
Daughter of Clymenus and wife of Nestor Od. 3.452.
in charge of the store-room Od. 2.347, T. bids her prepare provisions for his voyage 348;
she encloses the maids while Odysseus and T. remove the arms Od. 19.15;
washes O. Od. 19.357, recognizes his scar 392, 467;
encloses the maids before the fight Od. 21.380;
tells Penelope of O.'s return and the slaughter of the suitors Od. 23.1;
A comrade of Odysseus in his ship.
Leads one half of the ship's company to Circe's house Od. 10.205, remains when the others enter 232, tells their fate 244, follows O. to the house 447;
at the sacrifice on the borders of Ocean Od. 11.23;
with Perimedes-2 binds O. more firmly at the Sirens' island Od. 12.195;
insists on landing at the island of the oxen of the Sun Od. 12.278;
With Antinous leader of the suitors.
In the Ithacan assembly threatens Halitherses Od. 2.177; Penelope urged to marry him Od. 15.17;
abuses the disguised Odysseus Od. 18.349, throws a stool at him 387;
addresses O. on the slaying of Antinous Od. 22.44;
heads the suitors Od. 22.69, south Ο. 81; etc.

div.head: Εὐρυμέδων-1
div.p: Son of Ptolemaeus and chariot-driver of Agamemnon Il. 4.228.

div.head: Εὐρυμέδων-3
div.p: King of the Gigantes and father of Periboea-2 Od. 6.58.

div.head: Εὐρυνόμη-1.
div.p: She and Thetis kept Hephaestus secretly when he was rejected by Hera Il. 18.398, 399, 405.
A suitor, son of Aegyptius-1 Od. 2.22, Od. 22.242.

div.head: Εὐρύπυλος-2
div.p: Son of Euaemon and leader of the men of Ormenium, etc. Il. 2.736;
slays Hypsenor-1 Il. 5.76, 79, and Melanthius-2 Il. 7.36;
accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 6.167; Il. 8.265;
comes to the rescue of Aias-1 and slays Apisaon-1 Il. 11.576, 580;
is tended by Patroclus Il. 11.838, Il. 12.2, Il. 15.392, 399.

div.head: Εὐρύπυλος-3.
div.p: Son of Telephus by Astyoche, daughter of Priam.
Killed by Neoptolemus, his mother having been bribed by Priam with a golden vine to induce him to go to Troy Od. 11.520.
By contrivance of Hera born before Heracles, who thus became subject to him Il. 8.363, Il. 15.639, Il. 19.123, 133.
Punished in the house of Peirithous by the Lapiths Od. 21.295.

div.head: Εὔρυτος-1
div.p: The ruler of Oechalia Il. 2.596, 730: skilled with the bow Od. 8.224;
challenged Apollo to a contest with the bow and was slain by him Od. 8.226;
left his bow to his son Od. 21.32.

div.head: Εὔρυτος-2.
div.p: See also Il. 11.709, 750, Il. 23.638 under Κτέατος.
Son of Troezenus and leader of the Cicones Il. 2.846.
bids Menelaus. quit P.'s body Il. 17.12;
will avenge the slaying by M. of his brother Hyperenor Il. 17.34.
Son of Poseidon (nominally of Aloeus) and Iphimedeia.

div.head: Ἐφύρη-1
div.p: A town on the Selleis-2, the home of Astyocheia Il. 2.659, Il. 15.531.

div.head: Ἐφύρη-2.
div.p: A town of Argos-1 (3), the home of Sisyphus Il. 7.152, 210.

div.head: Ἐφύρη-3
div.p: A city or district, perh. in Thesprotia, the seat of Ilus-2 Od. 1.259, Od. 2.328.
A people represented as warred on by Ares Il. 13.301.
Son of Priam (his mother not named).
With his brother Chromius-2 killed by Diomedes Il. 5.160.

div.head: Ἐχέπωλος-2.
div.p: Gave Agamemnon the mare Aethe to escape service Il. 23.296.
A mythical destructive king Od. 18.85, 116, Od. 21.308.
The Echinean Islands, represented as lying off Elis Il. 2.625.
An island forming part of the realm of Odysseus Il. 2.634.
In Od. associated with Doulichium, Same and Ithaca Od. 1.246, Od. 9.24, Od. 16.123, 250, Od. 19.131.
A town of the Troad on the Aesepus-1 Il. 2.824, Il. 4.103, 121.
Διόθεν [-θεν], from Z. Il. 24.194, 561. By his power or will Il. 15.489.

(ἀθάνατος, αἰγίοχος, ἄναξ, ἀργικέραυνος, ἄριστος, ἀστεροπητής, ἐριβρεμέτης, ἐρίγδουπος, ἐρισθενής, εὐρύοπα, Ἰδαῖος, ἱκετήσιος, καταχθόνιος, κελαινεφής, κρείων, κύδιστος, μέγας, μέγιστος, Ἴδηθεν )Δωδώνης( μεδέων, μητίετα, αἰθέρι?̔τηλόθἰ ναίων, νεφεληγερέτα, ξείνιος, ξένιος, Ὀλύμπιος, πανομφαῖος, πατήρ, π. ἀνδρῶν τε θεῶν τε, στεροπηγερέτα, τελεσφόρος, τερπικέραυνος, ὕπατος, ὕ. κρειόντων, ὑπερμενής, ὑψιβρεμέτης, ὑψίζυγος, ὑψόθ̓ ἐών.)
The supreme god, son of Cronus and Rhea, brother of Poseidon, Hades, Hera and Demeter, and husband (and brother) of Here.

Father (1) by Hera of Ares, Hebe and Hephaestus; (2) by Leto of Apollo and Artemis; (3) by Dione of Aphrodite; (4) by Semele of Dionysus; (5) by Maia of Hermes; (6) by Demeter of Persephoneia; (7) by Europa (daughter of Phoenix-2) of Minos and Rhadamanthys; (8) by Leda of Helen; (9) by Alemene of Heracles; (10) by Laodameia of Sarpedon; (11) by Danaee of Perseus-1; (12) by Antiope of Amphion-2 and Zethus; (13) by Dia of Peirithous; and (14) by unnamed mothers of Athene, Dardanus-1, Aeacus and Tantalus.
And of strangers, beggars and suppliants Od. 7.207, Od. 9.270, etc.
See also ξείνιος 1, ξένιος 2 in Lex.
His thunderbolts Il. 8.133, Il. 21.198, etc.: Od. 5.128, Od. 12.415, etc.
Sender of rain Il. 12.25, etc.: Od. 9.111, etc.
And of the rainbow Il. 11.27, Il. 17.547.
By lot (Il. 15.187, 192) got the heavens and the upper air as his realm (but he is called καταχθόνιος 457).
The attempt of Here, Athene and Poseidon to put him in bonds Il. 1.399; Thetis goes to him on behalf of Achilles Il. 1.493, his promise to her 518;
sends Oneirus to beguile Agamemnon Il. 2.8;
sends Athene to induce the Trojans to break the truce Il. 4.70;
with threats forbids the assembled gods to help either side Il. 8.1;
sends a thunderbolt which falls before the chariot of Diomedes Il. 8.133;
sends an omen to comfort Agamemnon Il. 8.247;
sends Iris to turn back Hera and Athene Il. 8.399;
sends Eris to encourage the Greeks Il. 11.3;
sends Iris to Hector with advice Il. 11.185;
beguiled and lulled to sleep by Hera Il. 14.292, his rage when he awakes Il. 15.4;
summons Iris and Apollo Il. 15.54, sends her to bid Poseidon retire from the fight 158, and him to aid Hector 221;

debates with himself as to Sarpedon's fate Il. 16.433, resolves on his death 458, charges Apollo with his funeral rites 667; Hera tricked him in the matter of the birth of Heracles Il. 19.95, his rage thereat 125;
sends Athene to comfort Achilles Il. 19.342;
summons an assembly of the gods Od. 3.4, allows the gods to take sides in the fight 20;
pities Hector's plight Il. 22.168, but allows Athene to go to the assistance of Achilles 183;

sends Thetis to Achilles to induce him to give up Hector's corpse Il. 24.104, and Iris to Priam to bid him go to the ships and ransom the corpse 144, sends Hermes to aid Il. 17.334, etc. : speaks of Aegisthus to the assembled gods Od. 1.31;
sends an eagle as a good omen to Telemachus Od. 2.146;
sends Hermes to bid Calypso let Odysseus go Od. 5.29, Od. 6.261;
thunders as a good sign to O. Od. 20.103;
gives his voice for peace between O. and his people Od. 24.478, and sends a thunderbolt to stop the fighting 539;
With his brother Amphion-2 represented as having founded Thebes-1 Od. 11.262; Od. 19.523 (see also Πανδάρεος).
Acts as cup-bearer to the gods Il. 4.2;
helps Hera to prepare a chariot Il. 5.722;
tends Ares when cured of his wound Il. 5.905: Heracles her husband Od. 11.603.
The Sun, father by Perse of Aeetes and Circe Od. 10.138, and by Neaera of Phaethousa and Lampetie Od. 12.132.
Brings to Hephaestus news of his dishonour by Ares Od. 8.271;
his oxen Od. 1.8, Od. 12.128, they are killed by the companions of Odysseus 353.

div.head: Ἠετίων-1
div.p: King of Thebe-2 and father of Andromache.
His city taken by Achilles and himself slain Il. 1.366, Il. 7.416, Il. 9.188, Il. 16.153; Il. 7.395, 396, Il. 8.187, Il. 22.472, 480, Il. 23.827.

div.head: Ἠετίων-2.
div.p: A Trojan, father of Podes Il. 17.575, 590.
A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.561.

A town and country in the north west extremity of the
Peloponnesus Il. 2.615, 626, Il. 11.673, 686, 698: Od. 4.635, Od. 13.275, Od. 15.298, Od. 21.347, Od. 24.431.
Its men led by Polypoetes and Leonteus Il. 2.739.
Son of Thebeus-1. Chariot-driver to Hector.

div.head: Ἦνοψ-1.
div.p: Father of Satnius by a naiad Il. 14.445;
and father also of Thesto Il. 16.401.
(θεῖος, θρασυμέμνων θυμολέων, κρατερός, κρατερόφρων, μεγάλων ἐπιίστωρ ἔργων, μένος αἰὲν ἀτειρής).
Son of Alemene by Zeus (nominally by Amphitryon) Il. 14.324: Od. 11.267.
Father of Tlepolemus-1 by Astyocheia Il. 2.658, 666;
father also of Thessalus Il. 2.679: husband of Hebe Od. 11.603.
His birth delayed by contrivance of Here, whereby he became subject to Eurystheus Il. 19.95, Il. 15.640;
wounded Hera with an arrow Il. 5.392;
being wronged by Laomedon sacked Troy Il. 5.638, his return thence hindered by Hera Il. 14.249, 266, Il. 15.25;
carried off the dog of Hades Il. 8.366: Od. 11.623;
the wall built for him against the sea monster Od. 3.145;
his phantom in the Shades Od. 11.601;
Adj. fr. Ἡρακλέης. βίη Ἡρακλείη, Ἡρακλέης 658, 666, Il. 5.638, Il. 11.690, Il. 15.640, Il. 19.98: Od. 11.601.
(Ἀργείη, βοῶπις, Διὸς κυδρὴ παράκοιτις, ἠΰκομος, θεά, λευκώλενος, πότνια, πρέσβα θεά, χρυσόθρονος, χρυσοπέδιλος).
Daughter of Cronus and Rhea, sister of Zeus, Hades, Poseidon and Demeter, and wife (and sister) of Zeus.
For her children see under Ζεύς.
Reared by Oceanus and Tethys Il. 14.200, 302.
She suspects the promise of Zeus to Thetis Il. 1.536;
reproaches Zeus for favouring the Trojans Il. 4.20, they come to terms 31;
she urges Athene to the fray Il. 5.711, prepares a chariot 720, consults Zeus 753, conveys A. to the field 767;
urges A. again to the field Il. 8.350, they are stopped by Iris sent by Zeus 413;
arrays herself to beguile Zeus Il. 14.166, gets the aid of Aphrodite 188, and of Sleep 231, the beguilement 292, Zeus wakens Il. 15.4, and sends her to summon Iris and Apollo 54;
how she tricked Zeus in the matter of the birth of Heracles Il. 19.95;
summons Hephaestus to quell Xanthus-1 Il. 21.328;
in the Battle of the Gods assaults Artemis Il. 21.489;
(ἀμφιγυήεις, ἄναξ, κλυτοεργός, κλυτοτέχνης, κυλλοποδίων, περικλυτός, πολύμητις, πολύφρων, χαλκεύς).
Husband in Il. (Il. 18.382) of Charis, in Od. (Od. 8.267) of Aphrodite.
His lameness Il. 18.394, Od. 3.36, etc. : Od. 8.308, etc.
His craftsmanship Il. 1.607, Il. 14.166, Il. 18.417, 468, etc.: Od. 8.272, etc.
Persuades his mother to conciliate Zeus Il. 1.571;
made Agamemnon's sceptre Il. 2.101, and the breastplate of Diomedes Il. 8.195, and the aegis Il. 15.310; Thetis goes to beg him for armour for her son Il. 18.369, which he makes 468;
he tells how Eurynome-1 and Thetis tended him when rejected by Hera Il. 18.394; Hera summons him to quell Xanthus-1 Il. 21.330;

etc. : Od. 4.617, Od. 7.233, Od. 6.92; Demodocus tells how Ares and Aphrodite deceived him and how he punished them Od. 8.266, 270, 286, 287, 293, 297, 327, 330, 345, 355, 359; Od. 15.117, Od. 23.160, Od. 24.71, 75.
(δῖα, ἐΰθρονος, ἐϋπλόκαμος, ἠριγένεια, κροκόπεπλος, ῥοδοδάκτυλος, χρυσόθρονος).
Wife of Tithonus and mother of Memnon.
Carried off Orion Od. 5.121, and Cleitus-2 Od. 15.250.
Son of Eurytus-2 and grandson of Poseidon.
A leader of the Epeians Il. 2.620.
A Thracian bard deprived by the Muses at Dorium of his power of song Il. 2.595.
A town of uncertain site in the realm of Philoctetes Il. 2.716.
Daughter of Cisses (Il. 11.224), wife of Antenor, mother of Iphidamas and priestess at Tory of Athene.
opens Athene's temple for the aged women Il. 7.298, 302.
Son of Polypheides and great-grandson of Melampus.

In flight from Argos-1 (1) encounters Telemachus embarking for home at Pylus Od. 15.223, 256, 271, is taken on board 286, asks as to his disposal 508, announces a good omen 529, is committed to the care of Peiraeus 540; his prediction to Penelope Od. 17.151;
his vision among the suitors Od. 20.350, he leaves the suitors 363.
Abuses Agamemnon Il. 2.225, Odysseus deals with him 244, 246.
The inhabitants of Thesprotia, a part of Epeirus extending s.e. from the Thyamis Od. 14.315, 316, 335, Od. 16.65, 427, Od. 17.526, Od. 19.271, 287, 292.
Son of Heracles and father of Pheidippus and Antiphus-1 Il. 2.679.
Daughter of the ἅλιος γέρων (Nereus) Il. 1.556.
Wife of Peleus and mother of Achilles.

Comes when called upon by Achilles on his loss of Briseis Il. 1.357, A. reminds her how she saved Zeus from bonds 396, she promises to induce Zeus to favour the Trojans 413, goes to him and gets his promise 495;
received Dionysus when terrified by Lycourgus-1 Il. 7.136;
the chest given by her to Achilles Il. 16.222;

comes to A. on the death of Patroclus Il. 18.35, promises him armour from Hephaestus 127, goes to Η. 369, how Eurynome-1 and she preserved Η. 398, she brings away the armour 616, and gives it to A. Il. 19.3;

summoned by Zeus Il. 24.74, and sent to bid A. release Hector's corpse 104, etc. : appears and takes part in the funeral rites of Achilles Od. 24.47, the jar given by her to receive A.'s bones 73, the prizes given by her for his funeral games 85, 92.

div.head: Θῆβαι-1
div.p: The Boeotian city, traditionally said to have been founded by Cadmus (represented as having been founded by Amphion-2 and Zethus Od. 11.262) Il. 4.378, 406, Il. 5.804, Il. 7.223, Il. 10.286, Il. 14.114, 323, Il. 19.99: Od. 11.263, 265, 275, Od. 15.247.

div.head: Θῆβαι-2
div.p: The city of Upper Egypt Il. 9.381: Od. 4.126.

div.head: Θήβη-2
div.p: A town (inhabited by the Cilices), of which Eetion-1 was king, in the plain of Thebe in which Adramyttium afterwards stood.
Taken by Achilles and Eetion slain and Chryseis captured Il. 1.366, Il. 2.691, Il. 7.397, 416; Il. 22.479.
Son of Aegeus, king of Athens, and husband of Phaedra.
The great legendary hero of Athens.
Named as a warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.265: carried off Ariadne from Crete Od. 11.322; Od. 11.631.

div.head: Θόας-1
div.p: Son of Andraemon and leader of the Aetolians Il. 2.638;

accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 6.168; Il. 13.92; Poseidon takes his guise Il. 13.216, 222, 228; Th. advises the chiefs to stand up to Hector, sending the general body back Il. 15.281; Il. 19.239: in Odysseus's tale to Eumaeus and his companions Od. 14.499.

div.head: Θόων-1
div.p: With his brother Xanthus-3 killed by Diomedes Il. 5.152.
A nymph, daughter of Phorcys-2 and by Poseidon mother of Polyphemus-1 Od. 1.71.
(ἀντίθεος, δῖος, ἱππόδαμος, κυδάλιμος, μενεπτόλεμος, ποιμὴν λαῶν, ὑπέρθυμος).
Son of Nestor Il. 9.81, Il. 10.255, Il. 14.10;
Epithet or the name of the island containing the oxen of the Sun Od. 11.107, Od. 12.127, 135, Od. 19.275.
A town of Pylus Il. 2.592, app. identical with Θρυόεσσα
Son of Pelops, brother of Atreus and father of Aegisthus.
The sceptre left to him by Atreus and by him to Agamemnon Il. 2.106, 107: his dwelling Od. 4.517.
A town on the Scamander Il. 10.430.
An Egyptian, husband of Polydamna Od. 4.228.
A leader of the men of Orchomenus-1, etc. Il. 2.512, Il. 9.82.
The Ionians Il. 13.685 (app. identified with the Athenians 689).

div.head: Ἰάρδανος-1.
div.p: An unknown river, app. on the borders of Pylus and Arcadia Il. 6.135.

div.head: Ἰάρδανος-2.
div.p: A river of northern Crete Od. 3.292.
Demeter's love for him and his death by lightning Od. 5.125.

div.head: Ἴασος-1
div.p: Son of Sphelus and a leader of the Athenians.

div.head: Ἴασος-2
div.p: Ἴασον Ἄργος, of doubtful origin, app. denoting all southern Greece (Argos-1 (3)) Od. 18.246.
A town of the realm of Eumelus at the head of the Pagasaean Gulf Il. 2.712: was the home of Pelies Od. 11.256.

div.head: Ἰδαῖος-1
div.p: Summons Priam to take the oath to the Greeks Il. 3.248;
with Talthybius stops the fight between Aias-1 and Hector Il. 6.276, 278, 284;
sent to carry Paris's proposal to the Greeks Il. 6.372, 381, 405, 406, 413, 416;
accompanies Priam to the ships Il. 24.281, 325, 470.

div.head: Ἰδαῖος-2
div.p: With his brother Phegeus attacks Diomedes Il. 5.11, is saved by Hephaestus 20.
(μήτηρ θηρῶν, πιδήεσσα, πολυπῖδαξ, πολύπτυχος, ὑλήεσσα, ὑψηλή).
Husband of Marpessa and father of Cleopatra Il. 9.558.
Fought with Apollo for Marpessa Il. 9.559.
(ἀγαπήνωρ, ἀγαυός, ἀγὸς ἀνδρῶν, ἀγακλυτός, ἄναξ, ἀρήϊος, ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, δαΐφρων, δουρικλυτός, μεσαιπόλιος).
Son of Deucalion-1 and leader of the Cretans Il. 2.645;
described by Helen to Priam Il. 3.230;
visited by Agamemnon in his inspection Il. 4.252;

accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 6.165; Poseidon reproaches him Il. 13.219, he urges Meriones to the fight 249, slays Othryoneus 363, and Asius-2 384, and Alcathous 424, fights Aeneas 500;
strikes Hector Il. 17.605, retreats to the ships 624;
while watching the chariot-race is abused by Aias-2 Il. 23.474;
etc.: brought his surviving comrades safe home Od. 3.191;
in Odysseus's tale to Athene Od. 13.259, to Eumaeus Od. 14.237, in Eumaeus's comment 382, and in O. 's tale to Penelope Od. 19.181, 190.
The Argonaut, father by Hypsipyle of Euneus Il. 6.469, Il. 21.41: Od. 12.72.
(ἀμφίαλος, εὐδείελος, ἐϋκτιμένη, κραναή, παιπαλόεσσα, πίων δῆμος, τρηχεῖα, ὑπονήϊος).
The island home of Odysseus, containing the mountain Neritum (Neium) Il. 2.632, Il. 3.201: Od. 1.18, Od. 2.167, Od. 3.81;
πόλις alone Od. 1.185, Od. 15.37, Od. 24.205, etc.
ἄστυ alone Od. 2.77, Od. 17.25, Od. 22.77, etc.
Associated with Doulichium, Same and Zacynthus Od. 1.247, Od. 9.21, Od. 16.124, 251, Od. 19.132.
Adj. fr. prec., Ithacan Il. 2.184: Od. 2.246, Od. 22.45.
With Neritus and Polyctor-2 constructed a fountain above the city of Ithaca Od. 17.207.
Its men led by Podaleirius and Machaon Il. 2.729.

div.head: Ἰκάριος-1
div.p: A part of the Aegean south of Icaria and Samos, said to be named from Icarus, son of Daedalus, who fell into it from the air Il. 2.145.

div.head: Ἰκάριος-2
div.p: Father of Penelope and Iphthime Od. 1.329, Od. 2.53, 133, Od. 4.797, etc.
Son of Laomedon and father of Melanippus-2 Il. 3.147, Il. 15.576, Od. 3.238.
The Ileian plain cannot be identifed Od. 21.558.
(αἰπεινή, αἰπύ, ἐρατεινή, ἐϋκτίμενον?̔εὖ ναιόμενον̓ πτολίεθρον, εὔπωλος, εὐτείχεος, ἠνεμόεσσα, ἱρή, ὀφρυόεσσα).
For Ἰλιόθεν and for Ἰλιόθι as locative and Ἰλιόφι as genit. see Lexicon.

div.head: Ἶλος-1
div.p: Son of Tros-1 and father of Laomedon.

div.head: Ἶλος-2.
div.p: A ruler of Ephyre-3 represented as having command of poisons Od. 1.259.
An island lower in height than Samothrace between S. and Troy and n.w. of Tenedos Il. 13.33, Il. 14.281, Il. 24.78, 753.
comes to the aid of Odysseus when his raft is shattered Od. 5.333, 461.
Father of Charops and Socus Il. 11.450.
An unknown race described as living on (mare's) milk Il. 13.5.

div.head: Ἱπποδάμεια-1
div.p: Wife of Peirithous and mother of Polypoetes Il. 2.742.

div.head: Ἱπποδάμεια-2.
div.p: The eldest and the fairest and most skilful of the daughters of Anchises.

div.head: Ἱππόθοος-1
div.p: A leader of the Pelasgians (1) Il. 2.840, 842; Il. 17.217;
tries to drag off the body of Patroclus Il. 17.289.

div.head: Ἱππόθοος-2
div.p: A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.251.

div.head: Ἱππόλοχος-1
div.p: Son of Bellerophon, grandson of Glaucus-1 and father of Glaucus-2 Il. 7.119, 144, 197, 206, Il. 6.13, Il. 12.309, 387, Il. 17.140.

div.head: Ἱππόλοχος-2
div.p: With his brother Peisandrus-1 killed by Agamemnon Il. 11.122, 145.
Father of Ascanius and Morys Il. 13.792.
Comes to the Trojans from Zeus Il. 2.786;
calls Helen to the walls Il. 3.121;
leads Aphrodite from the fray Il. 5.353;
sent by Zeus to stop Hera and Athene Il. 8.398;
sent by him to encourage Hector Il. 11.185;
summoned by him Il. 15.55, and sent to cause Poseidon to retire 157;
sent by Hera to Achilles Il. 18.166;
summons the winds to the pyre of Patroclus Il. 23.198;
sent by Zeus to Priam Il. 24.143;
App. masc. form of prec.; the nickname of Arnaeus.
A beggar employed as a messenger by the young men in Ithaca.
(Ἶρος Ἄϊρος, that will soon be Irus no more), 75, 96, 233, 239, 333, 334, 393.
killed fighting with the Solymi Il. 7.203.
The town of the Cicones Od. 9.40, 198.
An Eleian slain by Nestor in his youth Il. 11.672.
A town in the realm of Protesilaus Il. 2.696.
Daughter of Icarius-2, sister of Penelope and wife of Eumelus.
Appears to P. in a dream Od. 4.797.
Son of Antenor and Theano; brought up in Thrace by his maternal grandfather Cisses and married a sister of Theano Il. 11.221.
Adj. fr. next. βίη Ἰφικληείῆ next.

div.head: Ἴφικλος-1
div.p: Son of Phylacus-2 and father of Protesilaus and Podarces Il. 2.705, Il. 13.698.

div.head: Ἴφικλος-2
div.p: Nestor beat him in a foot-race Il. 23.636.
Wife of Aloeus and by Poseidon mother of Otus-1 and Ephialtes Od. 11.305.
When Achilles took Scyrus-2 given by him to Patroclus Il. 9.667.
Son of Otrunteus and a naiad.

div.head: Ἴφιτος-1
div.p: Father of Schedius-1 and Epistrophus-1 Il. 2.518, Il. 17.306.

div.head: Ἴφιτος-2
div.p: met Odysseus in the house of Ortilochus-3 in Messene Od. 21.14, when he was seeking for lost horses 22 (though his and his father's home is stated to have been in Oechalia, far from Messene (see Εὔρυτος-1)); gave O. his father's bow Od. 21.31.
The home of Othryoneus of unknown site
The Thebans (see Κάδμος) Il. 4.388, 391, Il. 5.807, Il. 10.288: Od. 11.276.
Traditional founder of Thebes-1 (but see under Θῆβαι-1).
Father of Ino and Semele Od. 5.333.
A warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.264.
'Evil Ilius.' App. formed by Penelope Od. 19.260, 597, Od. 23.19.
A hill or mound on the Trojan plain of uncertain site Od. 3.53, 151.
A group of Aegean islands, part of the Sporades Il. 2.677.
the scene of the strife of the Couretes and the Aetolians Il. 9.530, 531, 577; Il. 13.217, Il. 14.116.
(δεινὴ φεὰ?̔αὐδήεσσἀ, δῖα?̔φεάων̓, δολόεσσα, ἠΰκομος, ἐϋπλόκαμος, νύμφη, πότνια).
Daughter of Atlas; dwelt in the Ogygian island.
Odysseus reaches her island and is detained by her there Od. 12.448; Od. 1.14, Od. 4.557, Od. 5.14, Od. 6.245, 254, Od. 21.452, Od. 9.29, Od. 12.389, Od. 17.143, Od. 23.333;
at the bidding of Hermes sent by Zeus she dispatches him to Phaeacia Od. 5.78, 85, 116, 180, 202, 242, 246, 258, 263, 276, 321, 372, Od. 6.260.
Having invoked the protection of Achilles against Agamemnon Il. 1.69, 86, declares Apollo's purpose 92, Agamemnon's reply 105; C.'s prophecy at Aulis Il. 2.300, 322; Il. 13.45, 70.
Father of Sthenelus-1 Il. 2.564, Il. 4.403, Il. 5.319.
Son of Assaracus and father of Anchises Od. 3.239.
The Carians, a people of southwest Asia Minor about the Maeander Il. 2.867, Il. 10.428.
An Aegean island, one of the Sporades Il. 2.676.
(Πριάμοιο θυγατρῶν εἶδος ἀρίστη, ἰκέλη χρυσέῃ Ἀφροδίτη).
Sought in marriage by Othryoneus Il. 13.366;
was the first to see her father approaching with Hector's corpse Il. 24.699: her murder Od. 11.422.
Mother by Priam of Gorgythion Il. 21.305.

div.head: Κάστωρ-1
div.p: Son of Tyndareus and Leda, brother of Polydeuces and Clytaemnestra and half-brother of Helen. H. misses him and his brother Polydeuces from the Greek host Il. 3.237.
The alternate immortality of C. and P. Od. 11.300.

div.head: Κάστωρ-2.
div.p: An alleged noble of Crete said by Odysseus in his tale to Eumaeus to be his father Od. 14.204.
An unknown people on the Trojan side Il. 10.429, Od. 3.329.
A people said to be in debt to Mentor-2 Od. 3.366.
A river flowing by Ephesus and into the Aegean Il. 2.461.
Acts as chariot-driver to Hector Il. 8.318, Il. 11.521, Il. 12.91, 92, Il. 16.727; Il. 13.790.
Killed by Patroclus Il. 16.738, the fight over his body 751, 754, 756, 759, 772, 781.
An unknown river, app. on the borders of Pylus and Arcadia Il. 6.133.
A savage race (but see Χείρων) app. inhabiting the regions about Pelion (Il. 2.744, Il. 16.143, Il. 19.390).
Fought with by Nestor in his youth Il. 1.268;
through the evil acts of Eurytion punished by Peirithous Il. 2.743: Od. 21.295, 303.
The general name of the peoples over whom Odysseus ruled Il. 2.631, Il. 4.330; Od. 20.210, Od. 24.355, 378, 429.
A Thracian people dwelling under Mt. Ismarus Il. 2.846, Il. 17.73: their town Ismarus raided by Odysseus Od. 9.39, 47, 59, 66, 165, Od. 23.310.
Prob. at the head of the Gulf of Adramyttium Il. 1.38, 452.
A people dwelling in darkness on the borders of Ocean.
His gift of a breastplate to Agamemnon Il. 11.20.
(ἀθανάτη, Αἰαίη, δεινὴ θεὸς αὐδήεσσα, ἐϋπλόκαμος, πολυφάρμακος, πότνια).
Daughter of Eelius and Perse and sister of Aeetes.

Her island reached by Odysseus and his surviving comrades Od. 10.135, half the force led by Eurylochus to her house 203, all but E. turned by her into swine 233, O. proceeds to the house 261, Hermes meets and instructs him 275, he is not affected by C.'s enchantments 314, his transformed comrades restored 388, he brings his other comrades from the ship 406;
after a year C. dispatches him and his comrades to the Shades 488;
she receives them on their return Od. 12.16, gives directions for their further voyage 37, they leave the island 144;
Father of Theano and maternal grandfather of Iphidamas.
Brought up I. in Thrace Il. 11.223.

div.head: Κλεῖτος-1
div.p: Son of Peisenor-1 and comrade of Poulydamas.
Daughter of Ides and Marpessa and wife of Meleagrus Il. 9.556, she prevails on M. to beat off the Couretes Il. 9.590.
A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.570.
A leader of the Boeotians Il. 2.495.

div.head: Κλυμένη-1
div.p: A handmaid of Helen at Troy Il. 3.144.

div.head: Κλυμένη-3.
div.p: Wife of Phylacus-2 and mother of Iphiclus-1 Od. 11.326.

Daughter of Tyndareus and Leda, sister of Castor-1 and Polydeuces, half-sister of Helen, and wife of Agamemnon, A. prefers Chryseis to her Il. 1.113: her treachery to A. and his murder and the murder of Cassandra Od. 3.266, Od. 11.409, 422, 439, Od. 24.199.

div.head: Κλυτίος-1.
div.p: Son of Laomedon and father of Caletor Il. 3.147, Il. 15.419, 427, Od. 3.238.
Nestor beat him at boxing Il. 23.634.
The chief town of Crete Il. 2.646; Ariadne's dancing-floor there Il. 18.591: the seat of Minos Od. 19.178.

div.head: Κοίρανος-2.
div.p: Saves M.'s life but loses his own Il. 17.611, 614.
Carried orders to Heracles from Eurystheus Il. 15.639.
A rock in Ithaca near the dwelling of Eumaeus and the spring Arethousa Od. 13.408.
Son of Caeneus and father of Leonteus Il. 2.746.
A people, app. neighbours of the Aetolians.
They joined with them in hunting the Calydonian boar, but strife arose over the division of the spoils Il. 9.529, 532, 549, 551, 589.
Avenging his brother Iphidamas wounds Agamemnon Il. 11.248, Il. 19.53.
Later Κάρπαθος, an Aegean island, one of the Sporades Il. 2.676.

div.head: Κρείων-2
div.p: King of Thebes-1 (not the same as the kinsman of Oedipus) and father of Megare Od. 11.269.
Husband of Tyro and father of Aeson, Phe=res and Amythaon Od. 11.237, 258.
With his brother Ortilochus-4 killed by Aeneas Il. 5.542, 549.
the realm of Minos Il. 13.450, 453: Od. 3.191, 291, Od. 11.323;
in Odysseus's tale to Athene Od. 13.256, 260;
in his tale to Eumaeus Od. 14.199, 252, 300, 301, Od. 16.62, Od. 17.523;
in his tale to Penelope Od. 19.172, 338.
App. a town of Ithaca Il. 2.633.
Genit. Κρονίονος Il. 14.247: Od. 11.620. Κρονίωνος Il. 21.184, 230: Od. 8.289. Dat. Κρονίωνι Il. 1.397, Il. 2.102, etc. Acc. Κρονίωνα Il. 1.502, Il. 2.350, etc.: Od. 14.406, Od. 24.472.
A Titan, son of Uranus and Ge, and by Rhea father of Zeus, Hades, Poseidon, Hera and Demeter Il. 2.205, Il. 4.59;
Places passed by Telemachus on his return from Pylus Od. 15.295.
in Nestor's tale of the fighting between the Pylians and the Epeians Il. 11.709, 750;
at the funeral games of Amarynceus Il. 23.638.
Named as ruler of the island Syria and father of Eumaeus Od. 15.414.
throws an ox's foot at the disguised Odysseus Od. 20.292, 303, 304;
wounds Eumaeus Od. 22.279, killed by Philoetius 285.
Daughter of Laertes and Anticleia and sister of Odysseus Od. 15.363.
A people represented by Menelaus as dwelling by the Iardanus-2 Od. 3.292;
in Odysseus's tale to Penelope one of the five divisions of the inhabitants of Crete Od. 19.176.
An island off the s.e. extremity of the Peloponnesus Il. 15.432: Od. 9.81.

A gigantic and savage race, represented (Od. 6.206) as being with the giants near the
gods.
an island off their land described Od. 9.116; Odysseus lands on the island Od. 9.142;
goes in his ship to visit the Cyclopes Od. 9.177;
A mountain of north Arcadia, sacred to Hermes Il. 2.603.

div.head: Κυλλήνιος-2.
div.p: Adj. fr. Κυλλήνη, a town of Elis Il. 15.518.
its town Paphos a seat of Aphrodite Od. 8.362;
its king Dmetor (according to Odysseus) Od. 17.442, 443; Od. 17.448.
Κύπρονδε [-δε], to (i.e. from as far as) C. Il. 11.21.
A town of the Peraebians Il. 2.748.
