Rivers of the underworld flowing into the Acheron, the A. being a tributary of the Styx Od. 10.513, 514.
An Aegean island, one of the Sporades Il. 2.677.
A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.585.
Only son of Arceisius, husband of Anticleia and father of Odysseus and Ctimene Od. 1.189, Od. 2.99, Od. 4.111, Od. 8.18, Od. 14.9, Od. 15.353;
his parentage and offspring Od. 16.118; Od. 22.185; Odysseus tries him Od. 24.226, he slays Eupeithes 520;
Of or pertaining to the Laestrygonians, a gigantic and savage race visited by Odysseus.
All O.'s ships but his own destroyed by them Od. 10.121.
The realm of Menelaus in general Il. 2.581, Il. 3.239, 244, 443: Od. 4.1, Od. 21.13.
With Phaethousa in charge of the oxen of the Sun Od. 12.132, 375.

div.head: Λάμπος-1
div.p: Son of Laomedon and father of Dolops-2 Il. 3.147, Il. 15.526, Od. 3.238.

div.head: Λάμπος-3.
div.p: One of the horses of the Dawn Od. 23.246.
Daughter of Bellerophon and by Zeus mother of Sarpedon Il. 7.197, 198;

div.head: Λαοδίκη-1.
div.p: The fairest of the daughters of Priam and Hecabe and wife of Helicaon Il. 3.124, Il. 7.252.
Daughter of Altes and mother by Priam of Lycaon-2 and Polydorus-1 Il. 21.85, Il. 22.48.
Son of Ilus-1 and father of Priam, Tithonus, Lampus-1, Clytius-1 and Hicetaon, also of Boucolion (bastard).
wronged Heracles in a matter of horses Il. 5.640, 649; Il. 6.453;
Peirithous and Polypoetes of this race Il. 12.128, 181 (cf. Il. 2.743): strife between the Lapithae and the Centaurs Od. 21.297.
Prob. a maritime town on the west of the southern Troad Il. 2.841, Il. 17.301.

div.head: Λειώκριτος-1
div.p: Son of Arisbas and comrade of Lycomedes.
A promontory (the south west termination of Mt. Ida) forming the south west angle of the Troad Il. 14.284.
The inhabitants of Pedasus-2 Il. 10.429, Od. 3.96, Il. 21.86.
(ἀντίθεος, βροτολοιγῷ ἶσος Ἄρηϊ, κρατερός, ὄζος Ἄρηος).
Son of Coronus and with Polypoetes leader of the men of Argissa, etc. Il. 2.745;
his defence with P. of the wall Il. 12.130, 188;
is third in putting the weight Il. 23.837, 841.
-ίδος. Adj. fr. next. Absol., a Lesbian woman Il. 9.129, 271.

The island (or more prob. the town thereof) taken by
Achilles Il. 9.129, 271; Il. 24.544; Od. 3.169, Od. 4.342, Od. 17.133.
The White Rock by which Hermes led the shades of the suitors Od. 24.11.
Wife of Tyndareus and by him mother of Castor-1, Polydeuces and Clytaemnestra Od. 11.298.
Also, by Zeus, mother of Helen Il. 3.236.
A Pelasgian, father of Hippothous-1 and Pylaeus Il. 2.843, Il. 17.288.
A leader of the Boeotians Il. 2.494;
The Aegean island, inhabited by the Sinties. Hephaestus's fall on to it Il. 1.593; Philoctetes left there Il. 2.722; Euneus sends wine from it to the Greeks Il. 6.467; Il. 21.230;
its king Thoas-2 Il. 14.230; Hera encounters ̔́γπνος there Il. 14.231, 281; Lycaon-2 sold into slavery there to Euneus Il. 21.40, 46, 58, 79; Il. 24.753: a seat of Hephaestus Od. 8.283, 294, 301.
Answers Mentor-2 in the assembly Od. 2.242.
Mother by Zeus of Apollo and Artemis Il. 1.9, 36, Il. 5.447, Il. 14.327, Il. 16.849, Il. 19.413, Od. 3.40, 72;
in the Battle of the Gods Hermes declines a fight with her Il. 21.497, 498, 502;
her revenge on Niobe Il. 24.607: Od. 7.106, Od. 11.318; Tityus laid violent hands on her Od. 11.580.
The suitors) seer; abstained from evil.
The first to try the bow Od. 21.144, 168;
appeals to Odysseus for mercy Od. 22.310, but is slain 320.
Libya, a country in the north of Africa.
Visited by Menelaus, described Od. 4.85; Od. 14.295.
Maternal uncle of Heracles, slain by Tlepolemus-1 Il. 2.663.
The (Epicnemidian and Opuntian) Locrians, inhabiting the coast lands facing the south and s.w. shore of the n.w. end of Euboea Il. 2.527, 535, Il. 13.686;

div.head: Λυκάων-2.
div.p: Son of Priam and Laothoe and brother of Polydorus-1 Il. 3.333; Apollo takes his form in inciting Aeneas Od. 3.81;
sold into slavery at Lemnos to Euneus but ransomed by Eetion-3 Il. 21.40; Achilles comes upon him at the river and slays him Il. 21.35, 116, 127; Il. 22.46, Il. 23.746.
The Lycians, a people of southwest Asia Minor (s.e. of the Carians) through whose territory the Xanthus-2 ran Il. 2.876, Il. 4.197, Il. 5.482;
many slain by Odysseus Il. 5.676; Il. 10.430, Il. 12.315, Il. 16.421;

div.head: Λυκόοργος-1
div.p: Scattered Dionysus and his attendants Il. 7.130, 134, his consequent fate 138.

div.head: Λυκόοργος-2.
div.p: Slew Areithous-1 Il. 6.142, 144, gave A.'s armour to Ereuthalion 148.
From Cythera, a follower of Aias-1.
A city of Crete Il. 2.647, Il. 17.611.
A town of the southern Troad perh. to be identified with the later Antandros.
Taken by Achilles and its king Munes slain and Briseis captured Il. 2.690, 691, Il. 19.60, Od. 3.92, 191.
The men of Magnesia described as dwelling about the Peneius and Pelion, led by Prothous Il. 2.756.
A river of Asia Minor falling into the Aegean near Mycale Il. 2.869.
Mother by Zeus of Hermes Od. 14.435.

div.head: Μαῖρα-1.
div.p: A nymph of Artemis, slain by her for an amour with Zeus Od. 11.326.
With Polyphontes leader of the ambush at Thebes-1 against Tydeus Il. 4.394, the only survivor 398.
The s.e. extremity of the Peloponnesus Od. 9.80.
Son of Melampus and father of Polypheides and Cleitus-2 Od. 15.242, 249.
A district n.e. of Athens facing Euboea Od. 6.80.
Son of Amisodarus and brother of Atymnius.
Wife of Ides and mother of Cleopatra Il. 9.557.
Son of Euanthes and priest of Apollo at Ismarus.
A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.562.
With his brother Podaleirius chief surgeon of the Greeks and leader of the men of Tricca, etc. Il. 2.732;
summoned to attend the wounded Menelaus Il. 4.193, 200;
wounded by Paris Il. 11.506, but rescued by Nestor 512, 517, 598, 613, in Nestor's hut 618, 651, Il. 14.3; Il. 11.833.
Son of Menelaus by a δούλη.
His marriage to a daughter of Alector Od. 4.11; Od. 15.100, 103, 122.
Daughter of Creion-2 and the first wife of Heracles Od. 11.269.
Son of Phyleus and leader of the men of Doulichium and the Echinean Islands Il. 2.627;

div.head: Μέδων-1
div.p: Bastard son of Oileus-1 by Rhene and brother of Aias-2.

Takes the place of Philoctetes as leader of the men of Methone, etc. Il. 2.727, Il. 13.693 (his followers here called Φθῖοι); dwelt in Phylace a fugitive, having slain a kinsman of his stepmother Eriopis Il. 13.695, Il. 15.334.

div.head: Μέδων-3
div.p: A herald of Odysseus left by him at home.
Tells Penelope of the plot against her son's life Od. 4.677, 696, 711, Od. 16.412;
his advice to the people Od. 24.439, 442.
Son of Amythaon and father of Antiphates-3 and Mantius.
As the price of the hand of Pero undertook to drive off the oxen of Iphiclus-1 Od. 11.291, but was put in bonds by Ι. 292, his release 294; he drove off the oxen Od. 15.235;
while in bonds had been wronged by Neleus Od. 15.230, avenged himself and gave Pero to his brother (who was named Bias) 236, fled to Argos-1 (1) 238, where he married 241.

div.head: Μελάνθιος-1
div.p: (αἰπόλος αἰγῶν.) Odysseus's goatherd, son of Dolius-2.
brings armour and arms to the suitors Od. 22.142, 152, 159, 161;
An unfaithful hand maid, daughter of Dolius-2.
Abuses the disguised Odysseus Od. 18.321, Od. 19.65;
Son of Oeneus and Althaea and husband of Cleopatra.
Died before the Trojan war Il. 2.642;
killed the Calydonian boar Il. 9.543, strife having arisen with the Couretes conceived anger against his mother and would fight no more 550, 553, persuaded by his wife beats the Couretes off 590.
A town in the realm of Philoctetes north of the Boebean Lake Il. 2.717.
(ἀγαθός, ἀγακλεής, ἀμύμων, ἄναξ, ἀντίθεος, ἀρήϊος, ἀρηΐφιλος, βοὴν ἀγαθός, διοτρεθής, δουρικλειτός, ἴφθιμος, κοσμήτωρ λαῶν, κυδάλιμος, ξανθός, ὄρχαμος λαῶν).
Son of Atreus, brother of Agamemnon, husband of Helen and father by her of Hermione; father also of Megapenthes.
fights Paris Il. 3.340, P. withdrawn by Aphrodite 380; M. wounded by Pandarus Il. 4.127, tended by Machaon 210;
takes and spares Adrestus-3 Il. 7.37, but Agamemnon slays him 63;
ready to accept Hector's challenge Il. 6.94, but is dissuaded 104;
cannot sleep and joins Agamemnon in rousing the chiefs Il. 10.25;
with Aias-1 comes to the rescue of Odysseus Il. 11.465;

bestrides the corpse of Patroclus Il. 17.1, kills Euphorbus 45, retires before Hector 108, returns with Aias-1 124, Hector retires before them 129, he shouts for help 248, Athene in the guise of Phoenix-1 urges him on 556, he kills Podes 575, dispatches Antilochus to Achilles 685, the corpse is at last rescued Il. 18.231;
takes part in the chariot-race Il. 23.293, Antilochus gains the advantage of him 417, he comes in third 514, accuses A. of foul driving 566, A. pacifies him 586;
etc. : after the taking of Troy advised, opposing Agamemnon, a return home at once Od. 3.141, sailed accordingly 157;
the death of his steersman off Sounium Od. 3.278;
receives Telemachus hospitably at Sparta Od. 4.1, tells him his adventures 333;
speeds him home with gifts Od. 15.68;
Son of Peteos and leader of the Athenians Il. 2.552, Il. 4.327;
in charge of part of the wall Il. 12.331, 373; Il. 13.195, 690, Il. 15.331.
With his brother Anchialus-1 killed by Hector Il. 5.609.

div.head: Μενέσθιος-2
div.p: Son of the Spercheius and Polydore, nominally son of Borus-2.
Son of Actor-2 and father of Patroclus Il. 9.202, Il. 11.605;
brought his son from his home in Opoeis to the house of Peleus Il. 23.85.

div.head: Μέντης-1.
div.p: In his guise Apollo urges Hector to avenge Euphorbus Il. 17.73.

div.head: Μέντης-2.
div.p: Son of Anchialus-2 and king of the Taphians.
In his guise Athene appears to Telemachus Od. 1.105, 180, 418.

div.head: Μέντωρ-2
div.p: A comrade of Odysseus in Ithaca left in charge of O.'s house and property.

His speech in the Ithacan assembly Od. 2.225; Athene takes his guise Od. 2.267 (urging Telemachus to go to Pylus and Sparta), 416 (accompanying T.), Od. 22.206 (in the fight with the suitors), Od. 24.502 (in the fight with the Ithacans); etc.
Father of Adrestus-2 and Amphius-1 Il. 2.831, Il. 11.329.
A servant bought by Eumaeus with his own funds from the Taphians Od. 14.449, 455.
Son of Talaemenes and a leader of the Maeonians
A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.582.
A fountain in Greece of unknown site Il. 7.457.
A town (no doubt maritime) app. in the later Messenia Od. 21.15.
A town in the realm of Philoctetes on the east shore of the Pagasaean Gulf Il. 2.716.

div.head: Μηκιστεύς-1
div.p: he overcame all in the funeral games of Oedipus Il. 23.678.

div.head: Μηκιστεύς-2
div.p: Assists Alastor-1 in carrying off the wounded Teucrus Il. 8.333, and Hypsenor-2 Il. 13.422.
The land of the Maeonians Il. 3.401, Il. 18.291.
a Maeonian, one of a people in the basin of the Hermus and the plain of Sardis Il. 5.43.
(ἀγὸς ἀνδρῶν, ἀτάλαντος Ἐνυαλίῳ ἀνδρειφόντῃ, δαΐφρων, δουρικλυτός, ἐΰς, θοῷ ἀτάλαντος Ἄρηϊ, μήστωρ ἀϋτῆς, πεπνυμένος).
Son of Molus and traditionally nephew of Idomeneus. ὀπάων of I. and joined with him in the leadership of the Cretans Il. 2.651, Il. 6.165;
accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 6.166;
kills Adamas Il. 13.567, and Harpalion 650, and Morys and Hippotion Il. 14.514, and Acamas-1 Il. 16.342, and Laogonus-1 Il. 16.603, Aeneas misses him 608;
superintends the bringing of wood for the pyre of Patroclus Il. 23.113;
takes part in the chariot-race Il. 23.351, comes in fourth 528, wins the archery contest 860, receives a consolation prize for spear-throwing, the contest not taking place 884;
A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.257.

div.head: Μίλητος-2
div.p: The city of the Carians near the mouth of the Maeander Il. 2.868.
A mountain range forming a promontory off which the north of Chios lies Od. 3.172.
Of the legendary race of the Μινύαι.
A river of Nestor's realm Il. 11.722.
Son of Zeus and Europa (daughter of Phoenix-2), brother of Rhadamanthys and father of Deucalion-1, Ariadne and Phaedra Il. 13.450, 451, Il. 14.322: Od. 11.322;
judging among the Shades Od. 11.568; Od. 17.523;

div.head: Μολίων-2.
div.p: In form a patr.; but see under Ἀκτορίων.
Traditionally a son of Deucalion-1 and brother of Idomeneus Il. 10.269, Il. 13.249.
Came from Ascania, son of Hippotion Il. 13.792.

div.head: Μούλιος-1
div.p: Son-in-law of Augeias and husband of Agamede.
A leader of the Phrygians Il. 3.186.
A promontory of Asia Minor off which the Icarian Samos lies Il. 2.869.

div.head: Μυκήνη-2
div.p: Said to have been the eponym of prec.
Brought into comparison with Penelope Od. 2.120.
Son of Euenus and brother of Epistrophus-2 Il. 2.692, Il. 19.296.
Said to have been an Amazon.
The followers of Achilles at Troy Il. 1.328, Il. 9.185, Il. 11.797, Il. 16.12, Il. 18.10, Il. 19.14, Il. 23.4, Il. 24.449, etc.
Applied with Ἕλληνες and Ἀχαιοί to A. 's followers Il. 2.684.

div.head: Μυσοί-1
div.p: The Mysians, a people east of the Troad, prob. having the Aesepus-1 as their west boundary Il. 2.858, Il. 10.430, Il. 14.512, Il. 24.278.

div.head: Μυσοί-2
div.p: A people of the far north beyond Thrace Il. 13.5.
Son of Nomion and a leader of the Carians Il. 2.867, 870, 871.
Son of Poseidon and Periboea-2 and father of Rhexenor and Alcinous.
Settled his people in Scheria Od. 7.7;
his parentage and progeny Od. 6.56, 62, 63; Od. 8.565.

she takes the washing to the river Od. 7.81, she and her maidens play 100, when Odysseus wakens she alone does not flee 139, O. 's appeal to her 149, her reply 187, she encourages her maidens 199, she bids O. prepare to accompany her and gives him counsel and information 255, she leads him to the city 316, her return home Od. 6.2;
Mother by Eelius of Phaethousa and Lampetie Od. 12.133.
Brought up in Scyros-1 Il. 19.327 : brought thence by Odysseus Od. 11.506, his exploits at Troy 510, slays Eurypylus-3 520;
(ἀντίθεος, γέρων, Γερήνιος, δῖος, ἡδυεπής, ίππηλάτα, ἱππόδαμος, ἱππότα, λιγὺς Πυλίων ἀγορητής, μεγάθυμος, μέγα κῦδος Ἀχαιῶν, μέγας, οὖρος Ἀχαιῶν, ποιμὴν λαῶν, Πυλοιγενὴς βασιλεύς, ὑπέρθυμος).
King of Pylus, son of Neleus, husband of Eurydice and father of Antilochus, Peisistratus, Echephron, Stratius, Perseus-2, Aretus-2 and Thrasymedes.
Had reigned already over two generations Il. 1.247;
intervenes in the quarrel between Achilles and Agamemnon Il. 1.254; Oneirus appears to Ag. in his form Il. 2.21;
visited by Ag. in his inspection Il. 4.293;
reproaches the Greeks, no champion coming forward against Hector, and tells the tale of the fighting between the Pylians and the Arcadians Il. 6.123;
advises the burning of the dead and the building of the wall Il. 6.325;
is cut off in the fight Il. 8.80, but is rescued by Diomedes 99;
advises the setting of a guard Il. 9.52;
advises the restoration of Briseis with gifts Il. 9.94, and the sending of the embassy 162;
is wakened by Ag. Il. 10.73, visits the guard 180;
carries off the wounded Machaon Il. 11.516;
his appeal in his hut to Patroclus and his tale of the fighting between the Pylians and the Epeians Il. 11.655;
his advice to Antilochus before the chariot-race Il. 23.306, is presented by Achilles with a remaining prize 615;
etc. : hospitably receives Telemachus at Pylus Od. 3.31, tells, him the tale of his return 102, advises him to go to Menelaus 317, dispatches him 474;
restrained the flight of the Greeks when Thetis appeared to take part in the funeral rites of Achilles Od. 24.50;
(ἀγαυότατος ζωόντων, ἀμύμων, ἀντίθεος, θεόφιν μήστωρ ἀτάλαντος, κρατερὸς θεράπων Διός, μεγάθυμος).

Son (Od. 11.241) of Poseidon and Tyro, husband of Chloris and (Od. 11.285) father of Nestor, Chromius-1, Periclymenus and Pero (in Il. 11.692 he is said to have had twelve sons) Il. 11.683, 717 : Od. 3.4, 409, Od. 11.254, 281;
his requirement of Pero's suitors Od. 11.288;
See Lexicon. Νηρεύς͂ the ἅλιος γέρων of Il. 1.556 : Od. 24.58, and the πατὴρ γέρων and γέρων ἅλιος of Il. 18.36, 141.
Perh. to be identified with the place of the name mentioned in Thuc. iii. 7. 4.
How Laertes took the place Od. 24.377.
A mountain in Ithaca Il. 2.632 : Od. 9.22, Od. 13.351.
In Od. 1.186 u.l. for Νήϊον. Νήριτον and Νήϊον seem to be the same.
Her children slain by Apollo and Artemis and she herself turned to stone on Mt.
Son of Charopus and Aglaia and leader of the men of Syme.
An Aegean island, one of the Sporades Il. 2.676.

div.head: Νοήμων-3
div.p: Lent Telemachus a ship Od. 2.386, Od. 4.630, 648.
Father of Nastes and Amphimachus-2 Il. 2.871.
Adj. fr. Νύσα, the mythical mountain sacred to Dionysus Il. 7.133.

div.head: Ξάνθος-1.
div.p: The divine name of the river of the Trojan plain west of Troy called (Od. 3.74) by men Σκάμανδρος.
Zeus his father Il. 14.434, Il. 21.2, Il. 24.693.
Σκάμανδρος?̔βαθυδινήεις, βαθυδίνης, δινήεις, δῖος, διοτρεφής, ἐΰρροος, ἠϊόεις) Il. 5.36;

div.head: Ξάνθος-2
div.p: A river of Lycia Il. 2.877, Il. 5.479, Il. 7.172, Il. 12.313.

div.head: Ξάνθος-3
div.p: With his brother Thoon-1 killed by Diomedes Il. 5.152.

div.head: Ξάνθος-5
div.p: One of the horses of Achilles by Zephyrus out of Podarge Il. 16.149, Il. 19.400, 405, 420.
A Boeotian town with a grove of Poseidon Il. 2.506.

div.head: Ὀδίος-1
div.p: A leader of the Halizonians Il. 2.856.

(ἀγακλυτός, ἀμύμων, ἄναξ, ἀντίθεος, δαΐφρων, Διὶ μῆτιν ἀτάλαντος, διίφιλος, διογενής, δῖος, δόλων ἆτος ἠδὲ πόνοιο, δουρικλυτός, ἐσθλός, θεῖος, θεοῖς ἐναλίγκιος, θρασύς, Ἰθακήσιος, κλυτός, κρατερός, κυδάλιμος, μεγάθυμος, μεγαλήτωρ, ποικιλομήτης, πολύαινος, πολύμητις, πολυμήχανος, πολύτλας δῖος, πολύτροπος, πολύφρων, πτολίπορθος, πτολιπόρθιος, ταλασίφρων, τλήμων, φαίδιμος).
(For the significance of the name see Od. 19.406.)
Only son of Laertes and Anticleia, brother of Ctimene, husband of Penelope and father of Telemachus.
In command of the ship conveying Chryseis to her father Il. 1.311, 430; Athene urges him to stop the flight homeward of the Greeks Il. 2.169, he deals with Thersites 244, exhorts the host 278;
described by Helen to Priam Il. 3.191;
visited by Agamemnon in his inspection Il. 4.329;
accepts Hector's challenge but does not get the lot Il. 6.168;
is one of the embassy to Achilles Il. 9.169, his speech 225, announces the result 677;

wakened by Nestor Il. 10.137, offers to go with Diomedes to penetrate the hostile lines 231 (see further under Diomedes); comes to the help of the wounded Diomedes Il. 11.396, is cut off 401, after doing much execution is wounded by Socus 434, kills him 447, is rescued by Menelaus and Aias-1 465;
advises against renewing the fight fasting Il. 19.155, 216, superintends the conveyance of the gifts to Achilles 238; his drawn wrestling-match with Aias-1 Il. 23.708, wins the foot-race 755;

etc. : his adventures on his way home; the Cicones Od. 9.39, the Lotus-eaters 82, the Cyclops 105, the island of Aeolus Od. 10.1, the Laestrygonians (all the ships lost but his) 80, Circe's island 135, Ocean, the Cimmerians, the Shades Od. 11.13, return to Circe's island Od. 12.1, the Sirens 146, smoke, breakers, roaring 201, Scylla and Charybdis 223, Thrinacia, the oxen of the Sun 260, the ship wrecked by violence of the wind, himself the only survivor 403, Scylla and Charybdis again 430, reaches Calypso's island 447, Hermes comes from Zeus to bid C. let him go Od. 5.29, he builds his raft 234, sets sail 269, Poseidon raises the sea 291, the raft shattered 313, Ino comes to his aid 333, lands in the mouth of a Phaeacian river and falls asleep 451, wakened by Nausicaa's maidens Od. 7.117, his appeal to N. 149, she conducts him to a point near the city 316, he proceeds to the city Od. 6.14, enters the palace of Alcinous 134, who receives him hospitably 167, he views the games and dancing Od. 8.109, is taunted by Euryalus-2 158, answers him 165, they are reconciled 396, 400, he throws the δίσκος 186, hears the lay of Demodocus 266, relates his adventures Od. 9.39, is conveyed with gifts in a Phaeacian ship to Ithaca Od. 13.70; Athene comes to him Od. 13.221, his tale to her 256, she transforms him into a beggar 429;

he proceeds to the hut of Eumaeus Od. 14.1, who receives him hospitably 48, his tale to Eu. 192, his tale of the night ambush 462; Telemachus appears at the hut Od. 16.11; Athene appears and retransforms O. Od. 16.155, O. reveals himself to his son 187, is transformed back to a beggar 454;
with Eumaeus follows Telemachus to the city Od. 17.200, they encounter Melantheus 212, they reach the city 260;

he follows Eumaeus into the house Od. 17.336, goes begging round the suitors 365,
his tale to Antinous 415, A. throws a foot-stool at him 462, he is summoned to Penelope 553, declines to go 561; his quarrel with Irus Od. 18.1;
abused by Melantho Od. 18.321, Eurymachus throws another foot-stool at him 394;
with Telemachus he removes the arms Od. 19.4; Melantho abuses him again Od. 19.66;

his tale to Penelope Od. 19.165, P. tests him 215, he tells of her husband and prophesies his return 262; Eurycleia ordered to wash him Od. 19.357, she recognizes his scar 392, 467, how he got the scar 393, she is silenced 479;
lies down to sleep in the πρόδομος 1, Athene appears to him 30, Zeus gives him signs 102; Ctesippus throws the foot of an ox at him Od. 20.287;
he reveals himself to Philoetius and Eumaeus Od. 21.193;
asks to try the bow Od. 21.275, Eu. gives it to him on the orders of Telemachus 359, he strings it 404;
kills Antinou Od. 22.8, Eurymachus vainly begs for mercy 45, the fight proceeds 79, Athene appears 205, slaughter of the suitors 297;

he summons the unfaithful maids for death Od. 21.431; Penelope comes to him but doubts Od. 23.85, her doubts resolved by his knowledge of the bed 174, he tells her of the trials that await him 264, the pair retire 289, he tells his adventures 310, he charges her with the care of the house and leaves the city 348;
he goes to try his father Od. 24.216, his tale to him 303, reveals himself 321, the fight with the Ithacans 520, stopped by Athene 531;
Sought Cassandra in marriage, promising to expel the Greeks.
His incestuous marriage with Epicaste Od. 11.271.
His funeral games referred to Il. 23.679.
Son of Antiphates-3 and father of Amphiaraus Od. 15.243, 244.

div.head: Ὀϊλεύς-1
div.p: Husband of Eriopis and father of Aias-2;

div.head: Ὀϊλεύς-2
div.p: With his comrade Bienor killed by Agamemnon Il. 11.93.
Ruler of Calydon in Aetolia, son of Portheus, husband of Althaea, father of Tydeus and Meleagrus, and grandfather of Diomedes Il. 2.641;
A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.585.
In Thessaly, the city of Eurytus-1.
Its men led by Podaleirius and Machaon Il. 2.730.
A town in the realm of Philoctetes at the extremity of the Magnesian Peninsula Il. 2.717.
Its men led by Polypoetes and Leonteus Il. 2.739.
In pl., the gods Il. 1.399, Od. 3.47.
(ἀγάννιφος, αἰγλήεις, αἰπύς, θεῶν ἕδος, μακρός, μέγας, νιφόεις, πολυδειράς, πολύπτυχος).

The Thessalian Mt. Olympus, the seat of the gods Il. 1.44, Il. 3.407, Il. 5.360, Il. 11.77, Il. 13.523, Il. 16.93, Od. 3.5, Il. 24.144, etc. : Od. 1.102, Od. 7.240, Od. 8.331, Od. 11.313, Od. 14.394, Od. 20.55, etc.
Priest of the Idaean Zeus and father of Laogonus-1 Il. 16.604.

div.head: Ὀρέστης-3
div.p: Son of Agamemnon and Clytaemnestra Il. 9.142, 284 : avenged his father's murder on Aegisthus and C. Od. 1.30, 40, 298, Od. 3.306, Od. 4.546; Ag. in the Shades asks Odysseus about his fate Od. 11.461.
Its men led by Polypoetes and Leonteus Il. 2.739.
A sim. patr. given to Ctesius Od. 15.414.
A town of Thessaly, prob. lying under Pelion.
Its men led by Eurypylus-2 Il. 2.734.
A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.571.

div.head: Ὀρσίλοχος-2
div.p: Odysseus in his tale to Athene says that he killed him Od. 13.260.

div.head: Ὀρτίλοχος-3
div.p: Son of the Alpheius and father of Diocles Il. 5.546, 547 : Od. 3.489, Od. 15.187, Od. 21.16.

div.head: Ὀρτίλοχος-4.
div.p: With his brother Crethon killed by Aeneas Il. 5.542, 549.
app. represented as to the south of the island Syria Od. 15.404.

div.head: Ὀρχομενός-1
div.p: A Boeotian town, the capital of the kingdom of the Minyae Il. 2.511, Il. 9.381: Od. 11.284, 459.
A mountain in Magnesia between Olympus and Pelion.
A leader of the Phrygians Il. 3.186.
Father of Iphition by a naiad Od. 3.384.
͂ οὔ τις. Odysseus's name assumed for the Cyclops Od. 9.366, 369, 408, 455, 460.
Heals Hades Il. 5.401, and Ares 899, 900: the Egyptians descended from him Od. 4.232.
The Paeonians, a people whose territory lay on the Axius Il. 2.848, Il. 10.428, Il. 16.287, 291, Il. 21.155, 205, 211.
The land of the Paeonians Il. 17.350, Il. 21.154.
A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.250.
All the Achaeans, the Achaeans in gen. (see Ἀχαιός 2.b) Il. 2.404, Il. 6.73, 159, 327, 385, Il. 9.301, Il. 10.1, Il. 19.193, Il. 23.236: Od. 1.239, Od. 14.369, Od. 24.32.
Father of Aedon (the proper name does not occur), who was the wife of Zethus and mother of Itylus. A. slew I. by mistake and was subsequently changed into a nightingale
(ἀηδών) Od. 19.518; P.'s daughters carried off by a wind (their parents being destroyed), but brought up by Aphrodite Od. 20.66.
The Trojan bowman, son of Lycaon-1.
Leader of the men of Zeleia Il. 2.827;
wounds Menelaus Il. 4.88, and Diomedes Il. 5.95, 795;
with Aeneas attacks D. E 168, 171, 246, and strikes him with his spear 280.
All the Hellenes (with extension of Ἕλληνες to the Greeks in gen.).
App hardly to be distinguished from Ἀχαιοί in the same line (see Ἀχαιός 2.b) Il. 2.530.
An elder at Troy, app. (Il. 16.807) a Dardanian, husband of Phrontis-1 and father of Euphorbus, Poulydamas and Hyperenor Il. 3.146, Il. 15.522, Il. 17.9, 23, 40.

div.head: Πανοπεύς-1
div.p: A town or district of Phocis Il. 2.520, Il. 17.307: Od. 11.581.
Carried off Helen from Menelaus and was her husband at Troy.

Appears in the front of the Trojans Il. 3.16, but retires before Menelaus 30, reproached by Hector 38, his duel with M. 340, he is snatched away by Aphrodite and set down in his chamber 380, Helen comes to him 421; Hector comes to urge him to the field Il. 7.321, he goes 503, and joins Η. 514, kills Menesthius-1 Il. 6.8;
in the assembly refuses to give up Helen Il. 6.355;
wounds Diomedes with an arrow Il. 11.369, and Machaon 505, and Eurypylus-2 581;
kills Euchenor Il. 13.660, and Deiochus Il. 15.341; Hector prophesies death to Achilles at the hands of P. and Apollo Il. 22.359;
how he flouted the goddesses Il. 24.28: etc.
A mountain of Phocis under which Delphi
Autolycus dwelt by it Od. 19.432, Od. 24.332.
A grace beloved by Hypnos Il. 14.269, promised to him by Hera 276.
(ἄλκιμος, ἀμύμων, διΐφιλος, διογενής, δῖος, θεόφιν μήστωρ ἀτάλαντος, ἱππεύς, ἱπποκέλευθος, μεγαλήτωρ, Πατροκλῆος λάσιον κῆρ).
Son of Menoetius and comrade of Achilles.
Brings out Briseis at the bidding of Achilles Il. 1.337, 345;
present with A. when the embassy arrives Il. 9.190;
summoned by A. to ascertain who was the wounded man who passed with Nestor Il. 11.602, reaches Nestor's hut 644, on his way back encounters and succours the wounded Eurypylus-2 807, Il. 15.390;
delivers Nestor's appeal to A. Il. 16.2;
arms at the bidding of A. Il. 16.126, and falls on the foe 257, fights with Sarpedon 427, slays him 480;

against A.'s advice drives the foe too far Il. 16.684, approaches the city 703, but retires before Apollo 710; Apollo brings about his end Il. 16.787, he is wounded by Euphorbus 806, mortally wounded by Hector 818, prophesies H.'s death 843, dies 855;

the
fight over his body Il. 17.1; Achilles hears of his death Il. 18.15;
his spirit appears to Achilles Il. 23.65, the material for the pyre collected 110, the pyre 163, the winds summoned to make it burn 192, the funeral games 262;
how he had been brought by Menoetius to the house of Peleus Il. 23.85;
in the Shades Od. 11.468, Od. 24.16; Od. 24.77, 79.
The Paphlagonians, a people of the south shore of the Euxine between Heracleia and Cape Carambis Il. 2.851, Il. 5.577, Il. 13.656, 661.
A comrade of Telemachus to whom T. committed Theoclymenus Od. 15.539, 540, 544, Od. 17.55, 71, 74, 78, Od. 20.372.
Son of Zeus and Dia (see Ἰξιόνιος), husband of Hippodameia-1 and father of Polypoetes Il. 2.741; Eurytion's disturbance at his marriage and the expulsion of the Centaurs Il. 2.742: Od. 21.296, 298;
a warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.263: Od. 11.631; Il. 12.129, 182, Il. 14.318.
A leader of the Thracians Il. 2.844;
slays Diores-1 Il. 4.520, 525, killed by Thoas-1 527; Od. 3.484.
With his brother Hippolochus-2 killed by Agamemnon Il. 11.122, 143.

div.head: Πείσανδρος-4
div.p: His gift to Penelope Od. 18.299; Od. 22.243.
Patronymic of Ops Od. 1.429, Od. 2.347, Od. 20.148.
Greets Telemachus at Pylus Od. 3.36; Od. 3.400, 415, 454;
eager for departure T. rouses him Od. 15.46, 48; Od. 15.131, 166;
they depart Od. 15.182, at Pylus takes T. direct to the ship to avoid Nestor's hospitality 202.
Comrade of Sarpedon, tended him when he was wounded Il. 5.695.
Adj. fr. next of equally disputed meaning.
Pelasgians, a name of much disputed meaning.
Applied to the men of Larisa Il. 2.840, 843, Il. 17.288 (in these two cases applied in sing. to Lethus).
(δῖοι) to a section of the Trojan allies whose position is indicated by Dolon along with that of the Carians and others Il. 10.429.
In Odysseus's tale to Penelope applied to one of the five divisions of the inhabitants of Crete Od. 19.177.
A town in Agamemnon's realm Il. 2.574.
Son of Tantalus and father of Atreus and Thyestes.
The sceptre given to him by Hermes and by him to Atreus Il. 2.104, 105.
The citadel of Troy containing (Il. 5.446) the temple of Apollo Il. 4.508, Il. 5.460, Il. 7.512, Il. 6.21, Il. 24.700.

div.head: Περίβοια-1.
div.p: Daughter of Acessamenus and mother of Pelegon by the Axius Il. 21.142.

div.head: Περίβοια-2
div.p: Daughter of Eurymedon-3 and mother of Nausithous by Poseidon Od. 6.57.

div.head: Περιμήδης-2.
div.p: A comrade of Odysseus in his ship Od. 11.23, Od. 12.195.

div.head: Περίφας-2.
div.p: Apollo addresses Aeneas in his form Il. 17.323.
A town of the Troad not far from the mouth of the Practius Il. 2.835, Il. 11.229, Il. 15.548.

div.head: Περσεύς-1
div.p: Son of Zeus by Danae and father of Sthenelus-2 Il. 14.320.

Daughter of Zeus and Demeter (it is no doubt to be understood that it was to the union in Il. 14.326 that she owed her being) and wife of Hades Il. 9.457, 569: Od. 10.491, 494, 509, 534, 564, Od. 11.47, 213, 217, 226, 386, 635.
Daughter of Oceanus and mother by Eelius of Aeetes and Circe Od. 10.139.
Father of Menestheus Il. 2.552, Il. 4.327, 338, Il. 12.331, 355, Il. 13.690.
A town, app. of the Troad, not identified Il. 13.172.

div.head: Πήδασος-2
div.p: A town of the southern Troad on the Satnioeis prob. to be identified with Assus opposite the northern end of Lesbos Il. 7.35;
With his twin brother Aesepus-2 killed by Euryalus-1 Il. 7.21.

div.head: Πήδασος-4
div.p: One of the horses of Achilles, taken by him at Thebe-2 Il. 16.152.
Son of the Axius and Periboea-1 and father of Asteropaeus Il. 21.141, 152, 159.
Son of Aeacus, husband of Thetis, and father of Achilles and Polydore.
His charge to his son Il. 9.252, Il. 11.783;
he received the fugitive Phoenix-1 Il. 9.480;
the visit to him of Nestor and Odysseus Il. 11.769;
his (and Achilles') immortal horses Il. 16.381, 867, Il. 17.443, Il. 23.278; Epeigeus came as a suppliant to him and Thetis Il. 16.574;
his armour, given by the gods Il. 18.84;
he received the fugitive Patroclus Il. 23.89;
his riches and good fortune Il. 24.534;
Of or pertaining to Peleus Il. 18.60, 441.
Of the spear of Achilles given to Peleus by Cheiron Il. 16.143, Il. 19.390, Od. 3.277, Il. 21.162, Il. 22.133.
A mountain in Magnesia, s.e. of Ossa.
The Centaurs driven from it by Peirithous Il. 2.744 (cf. Od. 21.295-304); Il. 2.757;
the spear of Achilles came thence Il. 16.144, Il. 19.391: the threat of Otus-1 and Ephialtes to pile Ossa on Olympus and P. on Ossa Od. 11.315.
A river of Thessaly reaching the sea through the Vale of Tempe Il. 2.752, 753, 757.
A leader of the Boeotians Il. 2.494; Il. 13.92;
Daughter of Icarius-2, sister of Iphthime, wife of Odysseus and mother of Telemachus.
Bids Phemius change his song Od. 1.328;
her stratagem in the matter of the web Od. 2.94, Od. 19.138, Od. 24.129;
hears of her son's departure and of the plot against him Od. 4.675;
appears to the suitors and rebukes Antinou Od. 16.409, is put off with fair words by Eurymachus 434;
welcomes her son home Od. 17.36, he tells her his story 108;
she hears the disguised Odysseus being struck Od. 17.492;
summons O. Od. 17.508, who declines to come at that time 560;
she appears again in the μέγαρον beautified (Od. 18.187) by Athene Od. 18.158, rebukes her son 215, relates to Eurymachus O.'s parting charge 250, suggests gifts 274, which are sent for 290;

when the suitors have gone appears again Od. 19.53, rebukes Melantho 89, converses with Ο. 103, bids Eurycleia wash him 357, he interprets P.'s dream 535; she sets down the bow, etc., for the contest Od. 21.1;

is summoned by Eurycleia after the destruction of the suitors Od. 23.1, cannot clearly recognize Ο. 85, to convince her he speaks of his bed 171, she recognizes him fully 205, the pair retire 289, he relates his adventures to her 310, his charge to her before leaving the city 350; etc.
Said to have been in Thessaly.
The horses of Eumelus reared there Il. 2.766.
Her father's requirement of her suitors Od. 11.287.
A district lying to the north of the Thessalian Mt.
Prob. to be identified with Lampsacus (the modern Lampsaki) on the Hellespont Il. 2.829.
(πλήσσω) rocks (represented also as smoking Od. 12.202) Od. 12.61, Od. 23.327.
A mountain dominating Thebe-2 Il. 7.396, 425, Il. 22.479.
A town of Aetolia Il. 2.639, Il. 13.217, Il. 14.116.
The Pleiades, a cluster of stars in the constellation Taurus Il. 18.486: Od. 5.272.
With his brother Machaon chief surgeon of the Greeks and leader of the men of Tricca, etc. Il. 2.732, Il. 11.833.
Dam of Xanthus-5 and Balius (see Ἅρπυια in Lex.) Il. 16.150, Il. 19.400.
Son of Iphiclus-1 and younger brother german of Protesilaus.
On P.'s death succeeded to his leadership Il. 2.704, Il. 13.693 (his followers here called Φθῖοι).
Son of Eetion-2 and boon companion of Hector Il. 17.575.

div.head: Πολίτης-2
div.p: One of the companions of Odysseus in his ship Od. 10.224.

div.head: Πόλυβος-2
div.p: Father of Eurymachus Od. 1.399, Od. 2.177, Od. 15.519, Od. 18.349, Od. 21.320, etc.

div.head: Πόλυβος-3.
div.p: The presents given by him and his wife Alcandra to Menelaus and Helen Od. 4.126.

div.head: Πόλυβος-4
div.p: Made the ball with which the Phaeacians played Od. 8.373.
Her gift of drugs to Helen Od. 4.228.
Son of Tyndareus and Leda, brother of Castor-1 and Clytaemnestra and half-brother of Helen.
Daughter of Peleus, wife of Borus-2, and by the Spercheius mother of Menesthius-2 Il. 16.175.

div.head: Πολύδωρος-1
div.p: Son of Priam and Laothoe and brother of Lycaon-2.
Killed by Achilles Od. 3.407, 419, Il. 21.91; Il. 22.46.

div.head: Πολύδωρος-2.
div.p: Nestor beat him at spear-throwing Il. 23.637.
With his brother A bas killed by Diomedes Il. 5.148.

div.head: Πολύκτωρ-1
div.p: Given as his father's name by the disguised Hermes to Priam Il. 24.397.
Daughter of Phylas and by Hermes mother of Eudorus.
Asks the Mycenaeans for aid in attacking his brother Eteocles Il. 4.377.
Son of Agasthenes and a leader of the Epeians Il. 2.624.
With Leonteus leader of the men of Argissa, etc. Il. 2.740; Il. 7.29;
his defence with L. of the wall Il. 12.129, 182;
wins the prize in putting the weight Il. 23.836, 844, 848.
Son of Mantius and father of Theoclymenus Od. 15.249, 256;
succeeded Amphiaraus in his seership Od. 15.252;

div.head: Πολύφημος-1,
div.p: (ἄγριος, ἀθεμίστια εἰδώς, ἀνδροφάγος, ἀντίθεος, κρατερός, μεγαλήτωρ, μένος ἄσχετος, πέλωρ).
One of the Cyclopes (q.v.), son of Poseidon and Thoosa (Od. 1.71).
Odysseus visits his cave in his absence Od. 9.216;
his cave and flocks described Od. 9.218;
he returns to the cave and finds O. and his companions there Od. 9.233;
his greeting and subsequent barbarous behaviour Od. 9.252;
is blinded Od. 9.371; O. and his surviving companions escape him Od. 9.424;
he prays to Poseidon for vengeance Od. 9.528;

div.head: Πολύφημος-2
div.p: A warrior of Nestor's youth Il. 1.264.
With Maeon leader of the ambush at Thebes-1 against Tydeus Il. 4.395.
θεράπων of Alcinous Od. 6.179, 182, Od. 8.65, Od. 13.50, 53.
Father of Agrius, Melas and Oeneus, and grandfather of Tydeus and Meleagrus Il. 14.115.
(ἄναξ, γαιήοχος, ἐννοσίγαιος, γαιήοχος ἐ., κλυτὸς ἐ., ἐνοσίχθων, κρείων ἐ., εὐρυσθενής, κυανοχαίτης).
Son of Cronus and Rhea, and brother of Zeus, Hades, Hera and Demeter.
Father (1) by Iphimedeia of Otus-1 and Ephialtes; (2) by Periboea-2 of Nausithous; (3) by Tyro of Neleus and Pelias; (4) by Thoosa of Polyphemus-1, and (5) of Cteatus and Eurytus-2.
By lot (Il. 15.187, 190) got the sea as his realm.
With Hera and Athene tried to put Zeus in bonds Il. 1.399;
complains to Z. of the building of the Greek wall Il. 6.445, with Apollo subsequently destroys the wall Il. 12.17, 34;
proceeds from Samothrace to the ships Il. 13.10, and encourages the Greeks 43, retires by order of Zeus Il. 15.218;
in the Battle of the Gods challenges Apollo Il. 21.436, who declines 461;
etc.: his bitterness against Odysseus on account of his son Polyphemus-1 Od. 1.20, 68; Telemachus finds the Pylians sacrificing to him Od. 3.4;
destroys Aias-2 on the Gyraean rock Od. 4.502;
raises the sea against Odysseus on his passage to Phaeacia Od. 5.291, Od. 6.271;
in the tale of Demodocus releases Ares Od. 8.344;
lay with Tyro in the Enipeus Od. 11.241;
turns the Phaeacian ship to stone Od. 13.159;
In neut. Ποσιδήϊον, a temple of P. Od. 7.266.
(ἀγαπήνωρ, ἀγαυός, ἀμώμητος, ἀμύμων, ἐγχέσπαλος, μεγάθυμος, πεπνυμένος).
Comrade of, and born in the same night with, Hector; excelled in counsel (Il. 18.249).
Advises against attempting the ditch with chariots Il. 12.60;
unsuccessfully advises H. to give up the attack Il. 12.210;

slays Otus-2 Il. 15.518;
eludes the spear of Meges Il. 15.521;
unsuccessfully advises H. to retire to the city Il. 18.249;
A river (now Bergaz Chai) flowing into the Hellespont on the Asiatic side Il. 2.835.
Applied to a wine of unknown growth Il. 11.639: Od. 10.235.
(ἀγακλεής, ἄναξ, γέρων, δαΐφρων, διοτρεφὴς βασιλεύς, ἐϋμμελίης, θεοειδής, θεόφιν μήστωρ ἀτάλαντος, μεγαλήτωρ, μέγας).
Son of Laomedon, grandson of Ilus-1, and great-grandson of Tros-1, who was son of Erichthonius, who was son of Dardanus-1, who was son of Zeus.

Father (1) by Hecabe of Deiphobus, Hector, Helenus-1, Laodice-1, Paris and Polites-1; also (though Hecabe is not here named) of Cassandra; (2) by Castianeira of Gorgythion; (3) by Laothoe of Lycaon-2 and Polydorus-1; (4) by unnamed mothers of Agathon, Antiphonus, Antiphus-3, Chromius-2 and his brother Echemmon, Dius, Hippothous-2, Mestor, Pammon, and Troilus; and (5) of Cebriones, Democoon, Doryclus, Isus and Medesicaste, all described as bastards.
At the beginning of the war had fifty sons Il. 24.495 (cf Il. 7.244), eleven of whom were by one mother, presumably by Hecabe Il. 24.496.
Twelve daughters and their husbands lived with him Il. 7.248.
Sitting on the wall he summons Helen to point out the Greek chiefs Il. 3.161;
is summoned to the plain to perform the oath-sacrifice Il. 3.250, returns 303;
advises sending to the Greeks to propose a truce for the burning of the dead Il. 6.368;
his charge to the gate-keepers Il. 21.526;

sees Hector in danger from Achilles Il. 22.25, and vainly beseeches him to take refuge 38; Iris sent by Zeus bids him go to the ships to ransom Hector's corpse Il. 24.171, Hecabe vainly dissuades him 201, his sons prepare his chariot 265, he departs 322, he encounters Hermes 349, he reaches the hut of Achilles 448, who receives him graciously 507, he retires to rest 643, he returns to the city with the corpse 689;

div.head: Προθοήνωρ-1.
div.p: A leader of the Boeotians Il. 2.495.
Son of Tenthredon and leader of the Magnetes Il. 2.756, 758.
Husband of Anteia. (See under Βελλεροφόντης) Il. 7.157, 160, 163, 164, 177.
Daughter of Erechtheus, king of Athens (grandson of the hero of the same name), and wife of Cephalus.
She is siad to have been unwittingly killed by C. with an unerring dart given to her by Artemis.
Son of Iphiclus-1 and elder brother german of Podarces.
Leader of the men of various towns lying about the west coast of the Pagasaean Gulf.
Was slain in landing first of the Greeks and was succeeded by Podarces Il. 2.698, 706, 708;
the position of his ships Il. 13.681;
the ship set on fire Il. 16.122, the fire extinguished 286, 293.
The Old Man of the Sea, a servant of Poseidon and father of Eidothee Od. 4.365, 385;
his transformations on being seized in Pharos by Menelaus and his comrades Od. 4.454, his advice to Μ. 471, tells of the fates of Aias-2and Agamemnon 491.

div.head: Πτελεός-2
div.p: A town of the realm of Protesilaus Il. 2.697.
A supposed (dwarfish) race represented as warred on by cranes Il. 3.6.
A town of Phocis, later called Delphi Il. 2.519, Il. 9.405: Od. 8.80.
Father of Harpalion and leader of the Paphlagonians Il. 2.851.
Killed by Menelaus Il. 5.576; Il. 13.643. (He is represented as alive in Il. 13.658.)
A leader of the Pelasgians (1) Il. 2.842.
In Il. 5.397 app. a different P. is meant.

div.head: Πύρασος-1
div.p: A town in the realm of Protesilaus with a τέμενος of Demeter Il. 2.695.
Son of Zeus and Europa (daughter of Phoenix-2) and brother of Minos Il. 14.322: in the Elysian Shades Od. 4.564;
the Phaeacians conveyed him to visit Tityus, app. in Euboea Od. 6.323.
By Cronus mother of Zeus, Hades, Poseidon, Hera and Demeter Il. 14.203, Il. 15.187.
Mother by Oileus-1 of Medon-1 Il. 2.728.
Son of Nausithous, brother of Alcinous, and father of Arete.

div.head: Ῥῆσος-1.
div.p: King of the Thracians; son of Eioneus-2.
His horses Il. 10.435, he and his comrades killed by Diomedes and Odysseus 474, 494, 519.
A river flowing through Phrygia and falling into the Euxine Il. 3.187, Il. 16.719.
The island home of Aias-1 Il. 2.557, Il. 6.199.

div.head: Σάμος-2
div.p: Il. 2.634 )with u.l. Σάμη(· 671, 845, Od. 15.29. Mod. Cephallenia, Cephalonia
An island forming part of the realm of Odysseus Il. 2.634.
In Od. associated with Doulichium, Zacynthus and Ithaca Od. 1.246, Od. 9.24, Od. 16.123, 249, Od. 19.131.
The channel between Ithaca and S. Od. 4.671, 845, Od. 15.29.
Son of Zeus by Laodameia (Il. 7.199) and with Glaucus-2 leader of the Lycians Il. 2.876;
is wounded by Tlepolemus-1 and slays him Il. 5.629, 633, 647, 655, 658, 663, Hector neglects him 683, he is rescued by his comrades 692; Il. 12.101, 292, 307;
his address to Glaucus-2 Il. 12.310; Il. 12.379, 392;
breaks the wall Il. 12.397; Il. 14.426; Zeus foretells his death Il. 15.67; Il. 16.327, 419, 433, 445, 464;
is mortally wounded by P. Il. 16.479, appeals to Glaucus-2 492, 496, dies 502; Il. 16.522, 533, 541;

the fight over his body Il. 16.553, 559, 638, 649, it is taken by the Greeks and stripped 663, Zeus charges Apollo with his funeral rites 667, 678; Il. 17.150, 162; Achilles sets down his armour as a prize Il. 23.800.
A river of the southern Troad falling into the Aegean a little north of Cape Lecton Il. 7.34, Il. 14.445, Il. 21.87.
Son of Enops-1 and a naiad.
Mythical beings (app. from the dual (Od. 12.52, 167) two in number) with irresistibly seductive voices.
Described Od. 12.39, 42, 44, 52, 158; Odysseus passes their island safely Od. 12.167, 198, Od. 23.326.
Father of Amphius-2; dwelt in Paesus Il. 5.612.

div.head: Σελλήεις-1.
div.p: A river of the Troad not identified Il. 2.839, Il. 12.97.

div.head: Σελλήεις-2.
div.p: A river in the country of the next, or according to others in Elis Il. 2.659, Il. 15.531.
The interpreters or priests of the oracle of Zeus at Dodona Il. 16.234.
Daughter of Cadmus and by Zeus mother of Dionysus Il. 14.323, 325.
A city on the n.w. of the Hellespont, a little above Abydus on the other side Il. 2.836.

div.head: Σθένελος-1
div.p: Son of Capaneus and companion of Diomedes Il. 2.564;
acting as chariot-driver to D. Il. 4.367, 403, Il. 5.108, 111, 241, 319, 835, Il. 8.114;
replies to Agamemnon in his inspection Il. 4.403, is rebuked by D. 411; Il. 9.48, Il. 23.511.

div.head: Σθένελος-2.
div.p: Son of Perseus-1 and father of Eurystheus Il. 19.116, 123.
A maritime city of Phoenicia Od. 13.285, Od. 15.425.
The inhabitants of prec., celebrated as craftsmen Il. 7.290, Il. 23.743: visited by Menelaus Od. 4.84; Od. 4.618, Od. 15.118.
Sicily in habited by the Sicani of history Od. 24.307.
Perhaps a people on the coast of Italy opposite Ithaca and the same as the Siculi of history.
In sing. of the female servant who attended to Laertes Od. 24.211, 366, 389.
A river of the Trojan plain north of Troy Il. 4.475;
its junction with the Scamander Il. 5.774; Il. 5.777, Il. 7.4, Il. 12.22, Od. 3.53, Il. 21.307.
The inhabitants of Lemnos Il. 1.594: Od. 8.294.
A mountain of Lydia, a branch of Tmolus.
Niobe turned to stone here Il. 24.615.
Father of Glaucus-1 Il. 7.153, 154: tormented in the Shades Od. 11.593.
A destructive female monster inhabiting a high rock opposite to the rock of Charybdis.

Killed by described Od. 12.85; Od. 12.108, 125, 223, 231; Odysseus passes between S. and Charybdis losing six comrades to S. Od. 12.235, 245, 261, Od. 23.328; Od. 12.310; O. comes again to the rock Od. 12.430, escapes Σ. 445.

div.head: Σκῦρος-1.
div.p: Neoptolemus brought up there Il. 19.326: Odysseus took him thence to Troy Od. 11.509.

div.head: Σκῦρος-2
div.p: A place (prob. not the same as prec.) taken by Achilles Il. 9.668.
The mouse-god, identified by the Greeks with Apollo.
Protector of Chryse, Cilla and Tenedos Il. 1.39.

App. a people inhabiting part of Lycia or a neighbouring country. Bellerophon's fight with them Il. 7.184; Isandrus killed fighting with them Il. 7.204: Poseidon descries Odysseus from their mountains Od. 5.283.
The s.e. point of Attica Od. 3.278.
The chief city of Lacedaemon Il. 2.582, Il. 4.52: Od. 1.93, Od. 2.214, 359, Od. 11.460, Od. 13.412.
A river flowing through Hellas into the Malian Gulf.
Father by Polydore of Menesthius-2 Il. 16.174, 176;
the lock of Achilles dedicated to the river Il. 23.142, 144.
A Greek of very powerful voice Il. 5.785.
(ἀάατον Στυγὸς ὕδωρ, κατειβόμενον Στυγὸς ὕδωρ, ὅρκος δεινός, Στυγὸς αἰπὰ ῥέεθρα).
The terrestrial Styx was a river and cataract in Arcadia (but the Titaressus is called (Il. 2.755) a branch of the Styx).
The name transferred to the chief river of the underworld Il. 8.369: Od. 10.514.
The Styx invoked in oaths (with app. confusion between the upper and under rivers) Il. 2.755, Il. 14.271, Il. 15.37: Od. 5.185.
An island to the north of Rhodes.
A mythical island, the home of Eumaeus, app. represented as to the north of Ortygia.

div.head: Σχεδίος-1.
div.p: With his brother Epistrophus-1 leader of the men of Phocis Il. 2.517.

div.head: Σχεδίος-2.
div.p: Also described as a leader of the men of Phocis.
The new home of the Phaeacians to which (Od. 7.8) they were brought by Nausithous Od. 5.34, Od. 6.79, Od. 13.160.
Wounds and with his brother Charops is killed by Odysseus Il. 11.427, 428, 440, 450, 456.
By the Gygaean Lake father of Mestheles and Antiphus-2 Il. 2.865.
Sent with Eurybates-1 to bring away Briseis Il. 1.320;
sent to bring the Greek oath-sacrifice Il. 3.118;
sent for Machaon to attend to Menelau Il. 4.192, 193;
with Idaeus-1 stops the fight between Aias-1 and Hector Il. 6.276; Il. 19.196, 250, 267, Il. 23.897.
Son of Zeus and father of Pelops.
App. a town of the Maeonians (Μῄονες) 44.
The gulf in which the Titans were confined.
The inhabitants of next, a piratical and slave-dealing race.
The largest of a group of islands lying between the island Leucas and Acarnania Od. 1.417.
He only in the Shades had his mental powers unimpaired (Od. 10.493).

Odysseus
sent to the Shades by Circe to consult him Od. 10.490, 524, 537, 565, Od. 11.32, 50, 89, 165, 479, Od. 23.323;
his converse with O. Od. 11.92, 139, 151; O. remembers his advice Od. 12.267, 272; O. relates to Penelope his advice and the troubles which he foretold Od. 23.248.
Father of Aias-1 and Teucrus Il. 8.283, Il. 13.177, Il. 17.284, 293: Od. 11.553.
An Aegean island in sight of Troy Il. 1.38, 452;
the cave between T. and Imbros where Poseidon shackled his horses Il. 13.33: Nestor puts in there on his return from Troy Od. 3.159.
The Grecian bowman, app. full brother of Aias-1 (see κασίγνητος 1.a in Lex.) Il. 7.31;
shows his archery against the Trojans Il. 8.266, 273, 281, 292;
aims at Hector Il. 8.300, 309; H. wounds him Il. 8.322,
wounds Glaucus-2 Il. 12.387, Il. 16.511, and Sarpedon Il. 12.400; Il. 13.91;
aims at Hector Il. 15.458, but his string breaks 462, 466, 484;
is beaten by Meriones in the archery contest Il. 23.859, 862, 883.
Associated with Oceanus in the rearing of Hera Il. 14.201, 302.
(δαΐφρων, θεοειδής, θεοείκελος, ἱερὴ ἲς Τηλεμάχοιο, κυδάλιμος, μεγάθυμος, μεγαλήτωρ, πεπνυμένος, φαίδιμος).
Only child of Odysseus and Penelope.

Referred to by his father at Troy Il. 2.260, Il. 4.354: in his absent father's house in Ithaca receives Athene who comes in the likeness of Mentes-2 Od. 1.113, she advises him to go to Pylus and Sparta 279;
prepares for the journey Od. 2.337, departs accompanied by Athene in the likeness of Mentor-2 413;
they reach Pylus Od. 3.1, he addresses Nestor 79, who bids him go to Sparta 323, he departs with Peisistratus 481;

they reach Sparta Od. 4.1, next day he tells Menelaus his errand 316, M. detains him hospitably 587; Antinous and companions lie in wait for him at Asteris Od. 4.774, 842; Athene urges him to go home Od. 15.10, he and Peisistratus depart 182, on reaching Pylus P. goes to his home leaving T. at the ship 193; Theoclymenus approaches him Od. 15.223, and is taken on board 279, they sail for Ithaca 284; T. lands near Eumaeus's hut to avoid the suitors and dispatches the ship to the city Od. 15.495;
he reaches the hut and finds his disguised father there Od. 16.11, his father reveals himself 187;
he leaves him and departs for the city Od. 17.1, is received by the maids and Penelope 31, disposes of Theoclymenus 71, tells his mother how he has fared 108;
his sneeze Od. 17.541; P. reproaches him for allowing ill usage of the disguised Odysseus Od. 18.215;
he and O. remove the arms Od. 19.4;
he arranges the contest for the suitors Od. 21.118;

he orders Eumaeus to give the bow to Ο. 369; arms for the fight and takes his stand beside his father Od. 21.431, kills Amphinomus Od. 22.91, brings arms 101, kills Euryades 267, is wounded by and kills Amphimedon 277, kills Leocritus 294, saves Phemius and Medon-3 354, carries out the slaying of the unfaithful maids 461;
he leaves the city with his father Od. 23.367, his father's address to him and the fight with the Ithacans Od. 24.506;
A seer among the Cyclopes Od. 9.509.
The city of the Laestry gonians Od. 10.82, Od. 23.318.
Patronymic fr. Τήλεφος, king of the Mysians-1.
The 'steep hill' of T. may poss. have been not far from Lampsacus, the modern Lampsaki Il. 2.829.
A mountain range west of Sparta Od. 7.103.
Husband of Eos and father of Memnon Il. 11.1, Od. 3.237: Od. 5.1.
A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.559.
Its men led by Eurypylus-2 Il. 2.735.
(in the MSS. Τιταρήσιος( ἱμερτός, καλλίρροον ὕδωῤ.
Now the Europus, flowing into the Peneius (in Il. 2.755 called a tributary of the Styx).
The waters of the two rivers do not mingle Il. 2.751.
The sons of Uranus and Ge, confined by Zeus in Tartarus. Here's oath by them Il. 14.279.
Rhadamanthys conveyed by the Phaeacians to visit him, app. in Euboea Od. 6.324;
laid violent hands on Leto and was tormented by vultures in the Shades Od. 11.576.

div.head: Τληπόλεμος-1
div.p: fights with Sarpedon Il. 5.628, 632, 648, and is slain 656, 660, 668.
A mountain range of Lydia south of Sardis Il. 2.866, Od. 3.385.
A town of Argos-2 in Hellas, near the mouth of the Spercheius Il. 2.682.
Its men led by Podaleirius and Machaon Il. 2.729, Il. 4.202.
A town in the realm of Diomedes (Argos-1 (1)) Il. 2.561.

The city of Troy (otherwise called Ἴλιος( )εὔπυργος, εὐρεῖα, εὐρυάγυια, εὐτείχεος, ὑψίπυλος, Τροίης ἱερὰ κρήδεμνα?̔ἱερὸν πτολίεθρον̓?̔λιπαρὰ κρήδεμνἀ 129, Il. 2.141, Il. 6.71, Il. 8.241, Il. 9.28, 46, Il. 13.433, Il. 16.100, 698, Il. 17.155, Od. 3.316, Il. 21.375, 544, Il. 22.478, Il. 24.256, 494, 774: Od. 1.2, Od. 4.146, Od. 5.39, Od. 11.510, Od. 13.137, 248, 388, Od. 14.469.
Τροίηνδε [-δε], to T. Il. 6.390, Il. 22.116, Il. 24.764.
The land of Troy, the district of which Troy was the capital
(ἀγαυοί, ἀγέρωχοι, ἀγήνορες, αἰχμηταί, ἀσπισταί, ἱππόδαμοι, μεγάθυμοι, μεγαλήτορες, πύκα θωρηκαί, ὑπερηνορέοντες, ὑπέρθυμοι, ὑπερφίαλοι, φιλοπτόλεμοι, χαλκοχίτωνες).
App. a separate clan of Trojans (the men of Zeleia) Il. 2.826.
From the Dardanians and allies Il. 3.456, Il. 6.348, 368, Il. 8.497.
From the Lycians and Dardanians Il. 8.173, Il. 11.286, Il. 13.150, Il. 15.425, 486, Il. 17.184.
In a sense corresponding to Τρῶες 2 Il. 16.369, Il. 17.724, Il. 21.296.
A son of Priam (his mother not named) Il. 24.257.
Trojan, like Τρωϊκός 2 Il. 5.461, Il. 13.262, Il. 16.393.
Absol. in fem. pl., (the) Trojan women

div.head: Τρώς-1.
div.p: Son of Erichthonius and father of Ilus-1, Assaracus and Ganymedes.
(ἀγαυός, Αἰτώλιος, δαΐφρων, δῖος, ἱππηλάτα, ἱππόδαμος, ἱππότα, μεγάθυμος, σακέσπαλος).
Son of Oeneus and Althaea, married to a daughter (Deipyle) of Adrestus-1 and father of Diomedes.
His mission to the Cadmeians Il. 4.384, Il. 10.285;
perished at Thebes-1 Il. 7.222, buried there Il. 14.114;
Husband of Leda and by her father of Castor-1 and Polydeuces Od. 11.298, 299.
Also nominal father of Helen Il. 3.236 (daughter of Zeus).
Daughter of Salmoneus and wife of Cretheus.
Brought into comparison with Penelope Od. 2.120;
by Poseidon mother of Pelies and Neleus Od. 11.235, 254;
by Cretheus mother of Aeson, Pheres and Amythaon Od. 11.235, 258.
A monster put in bonds by Zeus in the country of the Arimoi Il. 2.782, 783.
Made a shield for Aias-1 Il. 6.220.
The Hyades, a group of stars near the Pleiades Il. 18.486.
A Boeotian town Il. 2.500, Il. 5.708, Il. 6.221.

div.head: Ὑπέρεια-1.
div.p: A fountain believed to have been in the town of Pherae.
The people living about it led by Eurypylus-2 Il. 2.734; Il. 7.457.

div.head: Ὑπέρεια-2
div.p: The old home of the Phaeacians, near the Cyclopes Od. 7.4.

A town in Agamemnon's realm
Il. 2.573.
In reference to the flight of Polypheides hither Od. 15.254.
A Boeotian town on the Euripus Il. 2.496.
By Ieson mother of Euneus Il. 6.469.
With Lampetie in charge of the oxen of the Sun Od. 12.132.
One of the horses of the Dawn Od. 23.246.
The mixing-bowl given by him to Menelaus Od. 4.617, Od. 15.117.
Daughter of Minos and wife of Theseus.
Having calumniated her innocent stepson Hippolytus and being detected made away with herself.
(ἀγαυοί, ἀγχίθεοι, ἀντίθεοι, δολιχήρετμοι, μεγάθυμοι, ναυσικλυτοί, φιλήρετμοι).
A people, their home called Scheria, represented (Od. 7.204) as being the outermost of civilized communities.
Their transference from Hypereia-2 to Scheria Od. 7.3;
their ships and seamanship Od. 7.270, Od. 6.34, 108, Od. 8.557, Od. 13.76;
the skill of their women Od. 6.109;
their skill in dancing and ball-play Od. 8.260, 370;
conductors home of strangers and Poseidon's threat thereanent Od. 8.564, Od. 13.125, he turns to stone the ship that had borne Odysseus 159;

div.head: Φαῖνοψ-1.
div.p: Father of Xanthus-3 and Thoon-1 Il. 5.152.

div.head: Φαιστός-1
div.p: A city of Crete Il. 2.648: part of the fleet of Menelaus wrecked near it Od. 3.296.
A town in the realm of Menelaus Il. 2.582.
An unknown town, app. of Pylus or Arcadia Il. 6.135.
Son of Thessalus and with his brother Antiphus-1 a leader of the men of Nisurus, Cos, etc. Il. 2.678.
King of the Thesprotians Od. 14.316, Od. 19.287.
A town of the realm of Eumelus lying west of the Boebean Lake Il. 2.711: Od. 4.798.
A skilled craftsman; built ships for Paris.

div.head: Φέρης.-1
div.p: Son of Cretheus and Tyro Od. 11.259.
With his brother Idaeus-2 attacks Diomedes Il. 5.11, killed by Diomedes 15.
A bard who sang among the suitors under compulsion Od. 1.154, 337, Od. 16.252, Od. 17.263;

div.head: Φηραί-2
div.p: The home of Diocles Il. 5.543: represented as a half-way stage between Pylus and Sparta Od. 3.488, Od. 15.186.

The chief part of the realm of Peleus, of undefined position and extent, lying north of Mt. Othrys and west of the Pagasaean Gulf Il. 1.155, Il. 2.683, Il. 9.253, 363, 395, 439, 479, 484, Il. 11.766, Il. 16.13, Il. 19.299, 323: Od. 11.496.
Applied absol. to the followers of Medon-1 and of Podarces Il. 13.686, 693, 699.
A mountain of Caria not identified Il. 2.868.
Greets the disguised O. Od. 20.185; Od. 20.254;
ordered to close the gate of the courtyard Od. 21.240, closes it 388;
slays Peisandrus-4 Od. 22.268, and Ctesippus 285; Od. 22.359.

Leader of the men of Methone, etc., but left at Lemnos suffering from the bite of a water-snake and his place taken by Medon-1 Il. 2.718, the Greeks destined to bring him to Troy to their aid 725: his safe return from Troy Od. 3.190;

Menelau tells
how on an unspecified occasion in Lesbos Odysseus overcame him in wrestling Od. 4.343, Od. 17.134.
A people represented as warred on by Ares Il. 13.302.
The Phoenicians, a maritime and trading people, the inhabitants of prec. Il. 23.744 : Od. 13.272;
Phoenicia, a country on the coast of Syria between Mt. Lebanon and the sea Od. 4.83, Od. 14.291.

div.head: Φοῖνιξ-1
div.p: (ὰντίθεος, ἄττα γεραιέ, γέρων ίππηλάτα, Διῒ φίλος, διοτρεφής, παλαιγενής)
Son of Amyntor and an ancient retainer of Peleus.

Chosen to lead the embassy to Achilles Il. 9.168, his speech to Α. 432, tells how he fled from his father to Phthia, how Peleus received him well and how he brought up Achilles 478, he remains with Α. 658; a leader under A. Il. 16.196;
in his form Athene exhorts Menelaus Il. 17.555;
in the chariotrace set to note the running Il. 23.359, etc.

div.head: Φοῖνιξ-2
div.p: Father of Europa, the mother by Zeus of Minos and Rhadamanthys Il. 14.321.

div.head: Φόρκυς-1
div.p: A leader of the Phrygians Il. 2.862, Il. 17.218.
The Phrygians, a people on the Sangarius and about Lake Ascania Il. 2.862, Il. 3.185, Il. 10.431.
The land of the Phrygians Il. 3.184, 401, Il. 16.719, Il. 18.291, Il. 24.545.
A town in the realm of Protesilaus lying about ten miles west of the Pagasacan Gulf Il. 2.695, 700;
the home of Medon-1 Il. 13.696, Il. 15.335: the home of Phylacus-2 and Iphiclus-1 Od. 11.290, Od. 15.236.

div.head: Φύλακος-2.
div.p: Husband of Clymene-3 and father of Iphiclus-1 Od. 15.231.
Father of Polymele; brought up Eudorus Il. 16.181, 191.
By Areithous-1 mother of Menesthius-1 Il. 6.10.
A handmaid of Helen at Sparta Od. 4.125, 133.
The men of Phocis, in which Delphi (Πυθώ) was situated Il. 2.517, 525, Il. 14.516, Il. 17.307.
In Il. the wife of Hephaestus Il. 18.382.
Father of Nireus by Aglaia Il. 2.672.
With his brother Socus killed by Odysseus Il. 11.426.
A destructive female being inhabiting a whirlpool under a rock opposite to the rock of Scylla.
The rock and whirlpool described Od. 12.101; Od. 12.113; Odysseus passes between Scylla and Ch. Od. 12.235, 260, Od. 23.327; Od. comes again to Ch. and again escapes Od. 12.428, 430, 436, 441.
furnished Peleus with a spear from Pelion Il. 16.143, Il. 19.390.
A monster of divine origin described Il. 7.180.
Daughter of Amphion-3 and wife of Neleus Od. 11.281.

div.head: Χρομίος-2.
div.p: Son of Priam (his mother not named).
With his brother Echemmon killed by Diomedes Il. 5.160.
A leader of the Mysians-1 Il. 2.858.
A town of the southern Troad, prob. near the mouth of the Satnioeis Il. 1.37, 100, 390, 431, 451.
Captured by Achilles at Thebe-2 and given to Agamemnon Il. 1.369; Il. 1.111, 143, 182;
sent back to her father Il. 1.310, 439.
The priest of Apollo at Chryse, father of prec.
Comes in vain to the ships to ransom his daughter Il. 1.11, 370;

prays to Apollo Il. 1.37; Calchas declares that to stay the plague
his daughter must be restored Il. 1.93;
An island n.w. of Chios Od. 3.171.
An epithet or the name of Calypso's island of unknown meaning Od. 1.85, Od. 7.172, Od. 6.244, 254, Od. 12.448, Od. 23.333.
(ἀκαλαρρείτης, ἀψόρροος, βαθυδίνης, βαθυρρείτης, βαθύρροος, Ὠ. ποταμός).
Associated with Tethys in the rearing of Hera Il. 14.201, 302
Father (Il. 18.399) of Eurynome-1 and (Od. 10.139) of Perse.
θεῶν γένεσις Od. 14.201, 302. γ. πάντεσσιν Il. 14.246.
Parent of all waters Il. 21.195 (but see Ξάνθος-1).
A rock on the confines of Bouprasion Il. 2.617, Il. 11.757.
Carried off by Eos Od. 5.121, slain by Artemis 123;
carries on his hunting in the Shades Od. 11.572.

div.head: Ὦτος-1
div.p: Son of Poseidon (nominally of Aloeus) and Iphimedeia.
With his brother Ephialtes imprisoned Ares in a jar Il. 5.385: the size and beauty of the brothers Od. 11.308, they threaten to pile Ossa on Olympus and Pelion on Ossa 315.
Father of Eurycleia Od. 1.429, Od. 2.347, Od. 20.148.
